Lugano
The Italian spoken by Lugano's residents, the pasta and pizza on the outdoor cafe tables and the campaniles of the churches evoke the Mediterranean.
At the same time, Lugano, the cultural and business center of Switzerland's Ticino Canton, offers Swiss tidiness and calm, rather than the exuberance and bustle of Italy itself, which is just 15 miles away.
Two pyramid-shaped hills frame Lugano Bay on five-pronged Lake Lugano, which Switzerland shares with Italy; on jasmine-scented summer evenings, lights twinkle from the many villas, restaurants and cafes on the slopes.
The vegetation is subtropical -- palms, cypresses and oleanders, along with hundreds of rose varieties from May through October -- in the Civic Gardens and along the sweeping lakefront.


'On the Town' in Revival At Goodspeed Opera
WHY fight it?
The Goodspeed Opera House restoration of "On the Town" is captivating.
What Leonard Bernstein meant when he wrote of "the joy of music" is fully transmitted into the joy of a musical comedy.
This -- pure, simple, sweet, sentimental and funny -- is how it used to be.
Bathed in a very real nostalgia, here is the "New York, New York" of old: Lindy's, Luchow's, the Roxy (the movie palace, not the disco or the deli).
But not that old: The Hippodrome (the 5,000-seat showplace, not the garage) was razed.
"Tobacco Road" was already closed.


Biking Along Michigan's Hilly Shores
ON the beach in Frankfort, Mich., where the western sky glows until 10 o'clock on July nights, a young woman in baggy white shorts was lashing a couple of mountain bikes to a signpost.
She and some friends had just clambered off their boat from Chicago, she explained.
Chicagoans have been coming to the upper reaches of their lake since the days before air-conditioning.
These days, many of them bring their bikes.
My own was down the street, in the parking lot behind the Hotel Frankfort, on Main Street, about three blocks from the beach.
This was the eve of my four-day, 225-mile solo, haphazard cycling tour and this town of about 1,600 was my starting point -- about 300 miles from Chicago, roughly at the base of the Leelanau Peninsula, which cuts 30-some miles north into Lake Michigan.


Wall Street; The Rush Into Funds -- Less Than Meets the Eye
EVERY month brings new reports of record cash flows into mutual funds.
But those figures are just the numerators.
James A. Bianco, director of research at Arbor Trading Group, a Barrington, Ill., brokerage, looks at the denominator as well.
He compares the monthly flow not just to the previous month's, but to the total value of all stocks and bonds.
By this standard, stock and bond funds are still taking in less than they were before sentiment abruptly changed in 1987.

MAY 30-JUNE 5: People Power; In Guatemalan Politics, Epaulets Go Out of Fashion
In 10 days of upheaval, Guatemalans turned three times to the military that ran the country through decades of political murder and international opprobrium.
With the army command behind him, President Jorge Serrano Elias shut down Congress and the Supreme Court and suspended the Constitution on May 25.
Last week, with international repercussions mounting, the military reversed the move, under pressure from business, political and other groups, and forced out Mr.
Serrano.
Then, in a turn that outraged many Guatemalans, Mr.
Serrano's Vice President, Gustavo Espina Salguero, gained the military's support to take the presidency.

To the Editor:
"Managing Emotions in the Workplace" (The Executive Life, May 16), discussed only part of the new paradigm in today's work environment.
It is easy to overstate the effect of the decline of job security as a factor in the work force.
Too often people assume that loyalty to an organization is gone since there is a risk that their positions will not be permanent.
But consider the realities of professional sports.
If anything, job security is the exception.

Casinos Fear Competition in Backyard
WITH a mixture of pride and trepidation, the leaders of the casino industry in Atlantic City last weekend marked the 15th anniversary of the date when New Jersey made casino gambling legal.
Since 1978, the casinos have generated more than $30 billion in gross revenue, created more than 50,000 jobs, pumped $2.4 billion into the state treasury, paid hundreds of millions of dollars in property taxes to Atlantic City and added uncounted millions to the checking accounts of the businesses that service the industry.


LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
Holstein on Wheels
SITTING at a traffic light in a car that looks like a cow, one learns an important fact about New York drivers.
Nothing, not even pink udders on a Honda Prelude, will distract them.
Until the light turns green, the eyes stay straight ahead.
Which means that quite a few Long Island drivers missed quite a sight on Main Street in Smithtown.


Geraniums With That Continental Flair
FEW summer flowers do the yeomen work of geraniums.
These sturdy plants combine well with other summertime flowers for bright displays in window boxes.
Geraniums decorate tubs on the patio, and they provide bright accent color in borders where needed.
Geranium plants are rugged, too, and will survive the first blasts of cool weather.
They keep on flowering until truly deep freezes finish them off.
Each year sees brighter flower colors, stronger foliage and stems and unusual variety in geranium forms.


Top Graduates in Science Also Put Dreams on Hold

Seniors who had their hearts set on creating the technologies of the next century are having trouble just lining up job interviews, and fresh new Ph.D.'s are settling for temporary teaching jobs offering little prospect of the security of tenure.

Visiting 'Jurassic Park' For Real
They're probably as close to the real thing as movie dinosaurs will get, moving as naturally as animals in a National Geographic special.
The vegetarian dinosaurs nuzzle cute chicks, drool, snooze in the sun, roam savannas in picturesque herds and display distinctive personalities.
The carnivores bare serrated teeth, fix baleful eyes on their human prey and splash their way across lush Hawaiian landscapes.
All in all, the creatures in Steven Spielberg's big-budget science-fiction thriller "Jurassic Park," which opens on Friday, should, at the very least, amuse dinosaur lovers.
People watchers will have to make do with the performances by Sam Neill and Laura Dern as two young scientists in love, Jeff Goldblum as an eccentric mathematician, Sir Richard Attenborough as a billionaire -- "We saw him as a cross between Walt Disney and Ross Perot," Mr.
Spielberg said -- and two small children.


Oven-Stuffer Diamond
Synthetic diamond has been around for a half century, but a new method for making this precious stuff by roasting a plastic-like compound has caused a flurry of scientific excitement.
The latest advance in diamond synthesis, reported last week by scientists at Pennsylvania State University, was a tour de force of chemistry.
A team led by Dr.
Patricia Bianconi first synthesized a new polymer (or plastic), in which carbon atoms are bonded to each other in a lattice arrangement like that of diamond.
By roasting this substance in an ordinary oven, the extraneous material was driven off, and most of what remained was diamond.

Slow Fade to Black
When it comes to selling off chunks of Italy's cinematographic history, or at least the sets and props and costumes that marked its course, Antonio De Crescenzo is the person to call.
In 1981, he auctioned some 10,000 Roman tunics, several fiercely driven chariots and a number of passion-pummeled beds from 1950's and 60's blockbusters like "Quo Vadis" and "Cleopatra" at the renowned Cinecitta studio.


Salt Lake City Skiing Uphill on Bid
Salt Lake City, snubbed once before by the International Olympic Committee, has not lost a step.
This quiet metropolis, nestled within the Wasatch and Oquir Mountains, is pressing ahead at a bustling pace with its bid for the 2002 Winter Games -- despite possible derailment again by the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta.
At the United States Olympic Committee meetings here today, bid organizers unveiled a Utah Sports Development plan that would complete all facilities and bolster coaching staffs at the Winter Sports Park in time for the I.O.C. vote on June 16, 1995, in Budapest.
The bid by Salt Lake City already has the endorsement of the U.S.O.C., and Salt Lake City organizers took many of the directors on a tour of facilities that are sprouting 15 miles east of downtown.

West by West Puts His Feet in the Handicap Picture
In the hours before the festive air of Belmont Day was shattered, some of the best-known horses in racing competed in three major stakes leading to the main event of a day marked by extreme swings of fortune.
In the most important race on the undercard to the Belmont Stakes, eight senior stars of racing competed in the $400,000 Nassau County Handicap, the fifth event in the American Championship Racing Series.
And a new winner joined the seniors' tour: West by West, storming through the stretch to win by three-quarters of a length over Valley Crossing, who had a length on the hometown hero Strike the Gold.
And three and a half lengths farther back came the favored Devil His Due, who had already won twice in the series.


Gardeners Hope to Keep a Piece of Southern Black Culture Alive
More then 100 people gathered in a sunny field here today to pay homage to a spikey, hay-like plant -- sweetgrass -- that has long been essential to the black culture along the coast but is now endangered by development.
The volunteers, trowels in hand, planted more than 2,000 small clumps of sweetgrass on a one-acre inland plot on James Island, far from the sandy dunes where the grass once thrived.
The effort is part of an experiment to determine whether the plant can flourish under cultivation, and again supply the basket-making craft that has been part of black culture here for 300 years.

Challenge of Replacing Old Foundation Sills
OWNERS of older, neglected or poorly built houses and outbuildings, especially in rural or wet locations, often face the problem of replacing decayed foundation sills, the horizontal beams separating the framing of the building from the foundation walls.
Replacing the sills is seldom a job for amateurs, but doing so on a detached garage, shed or small barn makes a challenging, if strenuous, project.
Two helpful books before before starting the job are "Renovating Old Houses" by George Nash (Taunton Press, 1992) and "Renovation: A Complete Guide" by Michael W. Litchfield (Prentice Hall, 1991).
A useful article on sills was in The Journal of Light Construction in October.
The magazine may be available in libraries, or readers can call (802) 434-4747.


Time Bomb in the White House
President Clinton learned a valuable lesson when he appointed Bob Hattoy to work in the White House: Never hire a dying man; he has nothing to lose.
That was all too clear the morning that Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, called Hattoy at home to scold him for his latest transgression.
He hung up and ran to the bathroom.
"I went to my boyfriend while he was still taking a shower -- he had shampoo in his hair -- and I said, 'Bobby, will you still love me if I'm a waiter at the end of the day?' " Hattoy recalls.
"He said, 'Yes.' "

Serrano was to leave office in January 1996.

CLINTON FAULTED ON HAITI SANCTIONS
Even as the Clinton Administration adopts new sanctions to punish the military-backed Government of Haiti, officials of other nations and American analysts of Haitian affairs say Washington has failed to apply the type of pressure needed to restore the elected President, the Rev.
Jean-Bertrand Aristide, to power.
On Friday, with senior Administration officials' saying that they were imposing "a very high price" for the continued defiance by the military leaders of Haiti against international demands for a return to democracy, President Clinton signed an executive order freezing the assets of and barring travel to the United States by backers of the coup in September 1991 that overthrew Father Aristide.

U.S. Gives Up on a Chip-Making Tool, but Does It Matter?
A strenuous effort by the United States Government and the American semiconductor industry to save American manufacturers of a vital type of machinery used in making computer chips is ending in failure.
One of the last two major American manufacturers of that equipment, the GCA Corporation, went out of business last month.
The other, the Silicon Valley Group Inc., has concluded that it cannot continue on its own and is negotiating an agreement to license what is considered highly promising technology to an important Japanese competitor, Canon Inc., in exchange for financial assistance.

Shouting Obscures Arts Agency's Good Work
To the Editor:
"Waiting for the Appointment: Who Will Be the Arts Chief?" (The Week in Review, May 23) only perpetuates the false impressions of the National Endowment for the Arts thrust upon the public during the Reagan and Bush Administrations and only raises the same contentious issues that stifle dialogue and discredit the institution as a whole.
Always at the top of the dispute list is "obscene art." The work funded by the endowment that has stirred an outcry constitutes less than 1 percent of the agency's $175 million budget.
Robert Mapplethorpe, for example, spent much of his artistic energy on innovative photographs of flowers -- the black and white depictions of homoeroticism constituted a small, but nonetheless vital, part of his lifetime body of work.
The imposition of standards of decency can only turn funded works into formulaic colors on canvas, a contradiction of what artistic expression really is.
What should be kept in mind, though, is that a good deal of arts endowment dollars bring exhibitions and performance to rural areas of the United States where residents would not otherwise be exposed to or engaged in the artistic discourse of America today.
The endowment also aids in the genesis and production of ballet and operatic performance in cities, long suffering from both Federal and state cutbacks in funds.
The first job of the new head should be to enlighten citizens about the functions and benefits of the National Endowment for the Arts, and to dispel the misconceptions introduced during the last 12 years.
Only then can the agency engage the public in the multifaceted and forever evolving conversation we know as American art.
ELISE H. SANTANIELLO Woodcliff Lake, N.J., May 25, 1993


Putting on Walking Shoes for Clean Water


Bicyclists Pedal On, Despite Urban Perils
Although Devon Ruiz hung up his saddlebag a few years ago when he stopped being a bicycle messenger, he said the scrappy lessons he learned criscrossing avenues abuzz with the blurred cavalcade of traffic and pedestrians remain with him.
But there comes a point, in his mind at least, where luck overtakes road smarts.
"You can't be too cautious," he said Friday afternoon, pausing from his lazy glide along West 90th Street in Manhattan.
"You just have to ride and hope for the best." 2 Cyclists Dead and 1 Injured
The city's cyclists were hard pressed for hope last week.
Beyond the usual streetside hazards of chaotic traffic, foul-mouthed motorists and determined bike thieves, there came the dispiriting news: drivers without proper licenses struck two Manhattan men, killing one, while a drama teacher out for a sun-dappled spin in Brooklyn's Prospect Park was shot and killed during a bicycle theft gone awry.
The police arrested four teen-agers in the shooting.


Sailing to the Icy Top of the World
THE last time my husband and I swam from the bow of a ship it was in Bora Bora.
When we decided to take a cruise last summer to the Norwegian Arctic I packed my swimsuit but didn't really anticipated swimming in 35-degree water 567 miles south of the North Pole.
But plummet into frigid seas we did, along with 10 other hearty and slightly crazy souls who delighted in a quick dip in waters hospitable to polar bears, walruses and icebergs.
Our plunge took place near Spitsbergen, in the Svalbard archipelago, a group of islands covering 23,000 square miles (half of which is perpetually covered with ice) that is so far north -- 1,000 miles above the Arctic Circle -- that it is seldom visited by tourists.
We chose this destination because of its remoteness and the chance to see polar bears and pelagic birds in their natural habitats.
To our delight we got an unparalleled view of a polar bear and her cub and saw teems of nesting seabirds -- and because of melting ice and a skillful captain, our ship sailed farther north than it had ever gone before.

School Bill Is Viewed Many Ways
The State Senate gave final approval on Friday to legislation that requires every community in Connecticut to discuss the desegregation of public schools across town lines, but even in the last hours of debate, the expectations of what might result from those talks varied wildly.
Through the distorted glass of race politics, the opponents of the bill expect -- or fear -- the most from it, while many of the legislators who voted for it did so because they expect very little.


THE TELEPHONE TRANSFORMED
I read with great interest James Gleick's article on the near future of communications and information technology ("The Telephone Transformed -- Into Almost Everything," May 16).
As a researcher in computer science, I can say that for the most part he's right on the mark.
Still, there's an assumption, implicit in the article, that paper is "bad" and must inevitably be replaced by something better.
Consider Gleick's incredulity that Arno Penzias would maintain his phone directory, using such a low-tech medium as paper.
But what's wrong with this?
Paper is cheap, lightweight, fully interoperable with existing technologies (e.g. fax, copiers, filing systems, postal mail) and nonthreatening.
There are studies showing that people can read faster and with less fatigue from paper than from computer screens.

Orr Says He Will Remain at Iowa State
JOHNNY ORR, who talked of quitting as the men's coach at Iowa State earlier this year, says he'll honor his contract with the Big Eight Conference school.
Orr signed a contract extension last year that calls for him to coach the Cyclones through the 1994-95 season.
But when Iowa State recently shunned his application to become athletic director, Orr said he would quit if he could not agree with the school's choice of a successor for MAX URICK.


Kindergarten's 111th Story Ends Happily
Arms waving and feet kicking, the costumed kindergartners at Public School 95 danced merrily onto a small wooden stage and crooned "Razzle Dazzle" and "Ease On Down the Road" -- songs that echoed eerily last week through their Brooklyn elementary school auditorium and the memories of onlookers.
Three months ago the children began rehearsing those songs as they stood shivering on the observation deck of the World Trade Center, awaiting rescue after a bomb exploded 110 floors below.


Back East, a California-Born Master of the Deadpan
IN "Art of the San Francisco Bay Area" Thomas Albright notes that Joan Brown enrolled at the California School of Fine Arts not because she was interested in the subject but because she wanted to avoid the Roman Catholic women's school selected by her parents.
It was 1956, the year of her first marriage and two years before her first solo show in San Francisco.
So when she hit Manhattan in 1960 with the first of several shows at Staempfli Gallery, the artist, then 22 years old, was still something of a prodigy.
The canvases from this phase are loaded with pigment, much of it red; later on, when Ms.
Brown switched to enamel, the turbulence subsided but the ingenuousness remained for the rest of her life, which ended in an accident in 1990.
To judge from the 1970's works on view in the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford, the artist was selectively naive, producing an improbable painting of revelers one moment and sophisticated drawings of nudes the next.
A clue to her outlook may be found in six self-portraits in which the headgear changes while the face, with its large pale green eyes, remains consistently bland.
In these Ms.
Brown was as much a master of deadpan as is Ed Ruscha in his images with words.


MAY 30-JUNE 5: What's With Qaddafi?; Libyans Go to Jerusalem, or Pilgrims' Lack of Progress
After decades of conflict with the Arab world, Israel craves recognition from its neighbors.
So when a group of nearly 200 Libyan Muslims arrived last week on a pilgrimage to Jerusalem, there were those who hailed them as harbingers of peace.
They were given an official welcome, and some Government ministers and trip organizers speculated on possible ties with Libya and even a visit by its leader, Col.
Muammar el-Qaddafi.
Suddenly, things went awry.
The pilgrims' leader called for the "liberation" of Jerusalem from Israel, which he said was not a state, only the name of a prophet in the Koran.
Israeli officials announced that they would boycott the group, which in turn packed up and left.

Brown Is Late at Start But Early at the Finish
The Brown crew, the men's varsity eight that had hardly been tested this season, was a little casual and a little tardy in reaching the starting line today for the championship race of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association regatta on the Cooper River course.
And when the 2,000-meter race began, the boat from the University of Pennsylvania, Brown's foremost rival this spring, jumped into the lead and by 500 meters was almost a boat length ahead.
But then the Bears bore down, with 20 strokes of extra power.

Streetscapes: The Thalia Theater; A Restoration for a Threatened Parabolic Curiosity
NO, no -- this is all backwards.
Small movie revival houses on development sites are supposed to be demolished, not survive, and certainly not be restored.
But that's what's happening to the 1931 Thalia Theater, at 95th Street and Broadway, which is scheduled to reopen June 18 after six dark years.
New and old patrons will see the unusual Art Moderne design, the ticket counter, lounge and tile work brushed up, and be able to judge whether the radically different tilted floor is a gimmick or an innovation.


12th Season for Early Music Festival
THE Connecticut Early Music Festival celebrates its 12th season with a dozen concerts in eight locations, and an expansion of the term early music to encompass songs of Stephen Foster, even works for period instruments by seven contemporary composers.
The artistic directors, the flutist John Solum and the harpsichordist Igor Kipnis, help start the first recital -- recitals, actually, since the 6:15 P.M.
Friday program in Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London will be repeated there at 8:30 that evening -- with music of Telemann, Handel, Quantz, Boismortier and Hotteterre.


French Foursome Has Bermuda Bowl Hopes
BASED on past performance, there is a strong possibility that the final of the 1993 World Championship, which will be contested for the Bermuda Bowl in Santiago, Chile, in September, will be between the United States and France.
That would repeat the 1992 final in Salsomaggiore, Italy, when the French were victorious.
The Americans and the French have met on 19 official or semi-official occasions.
There have been six French victories, four of them en route to world titles, and 12 American victories.
A 1932 match was abandoned as a draw after a dispute.


Wall Street; New Curves in the Currency Game
FOREIGN markets provide at least 40 percent of the profits for the nation's 500 largest companies, so those companies are always desperate to find shelter from currency trading tempests.
The more so now that the world's mightiest currencies are getting bumped around like a bunch of biotech stocks.
Several leading manufacturers are feuding with securities and accounting authorities over proposed rules that, they say, would compound the risks of competing abroad, discouraging investment.
To the authorities, the issue is whether accounting standards can be twisted to disguise currency risks from investors.
"How well do we serve investors in those situations by working up some accounting conventions so things look nice and stable?" said Halsey G. Bullen, a manager at the Financial Accounting Standards Board.
"How well does that reflect economic reality? Life is volatile sometimes."

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
STUDIO OPEN HOUSE
The studio of William Chadwick, a member of Old Lyme's colony of 20th-century American Impressionist painters, will open today for public viewing, surrounded by gardens on the grounds of the Florence Griswold Museum.
The studio was donated to the museum by the artist's daughter-in-law, Elizabeth Chadwick O'Connell, and moved from its original site off Shore Road to the museum's property.
It has been restored to its appearance when Mr.
Chadwick painted there from 1920 to 1962.
Many of the original furnishings and accessories, and the artist's painting equipment were preserved and have been installed.


Eastham, Cape Cod's Little Secret
HALFWAY between the elbow and knuckles of Cape Cod, Massachusetts' long arm flexing into the Atlantic, lies a little town that most vacationers hardly notice.
"You can pass through the village centers of Eastham and North Eastham and never know you've been there," notes one guidebook.
And it's almost true.
Bisected by Route 6, Cape Cod's main artery, Eastham appears at first glance to have little of even passing interest, besides a glimpse of water and a vaguely hat-shaped visitor center.
To most hurried visitors, "the gateway" to the National Seashore, as Eastham is known, remains a stop for gas on the way to the beach; for those who pause a moment longer on their way to Wellfleet or Provincetown, it's a straggle of efficiency cottages, a few motels and a handful of slightly faded roadside attractions.
No blown glass, no band concerts, no yacht club.
But for those who linger, Eastham provides its own quiet blandishments.
The sun rises over the ocean on one edge of town, and sets a few miles away over Cape Cod Bay.
In between sunrise and sunset, you can swim across a couple of freshwater ponds, or brood by a salt marsh.
A watery, drifting place, Eastham loses a bit of itself every year to the tides, shored up only by beach grass and scrub pine.
Where the ground isn't spongy, it's sandy.
Long ago, I decided that this tentative quality must be why Eastham has stayed so unassuming, blessedly free of choked harbors, of restaurants that treat lobster as haute cuisine, of golf courses larger than half an acre.
Instead it's a mom-and-pop kind of town; the same family has always owned the general store, and a rented bicycle comes with a desultory chat about back roads, and a reminder to wear a helmet.
When you spot someone wearing Spandex on the bike path, you know he's ridden in from somewhere else.


At Work; Unions Call Out Their Troops
THE last time labor law reform was a serious possibility, Jimmy Carter was President, the Raiders were still in Oakland and Evelyn "Champagne" King was the reigning diva.
In 1978, labor law reform legislation died by the slimmest of margins.
The very notion of reform was laughable during the 80's, a period during which most unionists came to regard not losing too much ground as a victory.
The Republican banishment from the White House, if not entirely from power, has freed trade unionists from 12 years of chronic pain and allowed them to start dusting off some unused limbs.
Since January, a coalition of unions has been calling out troops to protest what some unions view as the lack of enforcement of current labor laws and to help raise the visibility of a campaign to make it easier for unions to organize.


Back in the Swim With Fresh Air Fund
While staying with a Massachusetts family last summer, Keenen Jackson, 11, of Staten Island, learned how to fish but not how to tell a fish story.
"I've caught fish in the pond," he announced proudly at a pizza party recently for Fresh Air Fund children from Staten Island.
But, holding his index fingers a few inches apart, he admitted, "They were really little fish."


Conversations/Herbert Jose de Souza; A Hard Look at Brazil's Surfeits: Food, Hunger and Inequality
BOOSTERS of Brazil like to point out that during the 1980's this enormous nation became the world's third largest food exporter, outranked only by the United States and France.
Herbert Jose de Souza likes to point out that during the 1980's, the legions of Brazilians who live with hunger expanded from 25 million people to 35 million people.


When Recipes Are Not Recipes, but Ideas
OVER the years, among the many major culinary trends, two polar-opposite positions have evolved in the recipe-writing business.
One sort of food writer assumes that the cook wants and needs to be told what to do in a prescriptive fashion -- make it work, make it beautiful.
But from the opposite camp come recipes aimed at some presumably smaller number of cooks who are confident enough and experienced enough to search out the cooking tutors who will simply show them the way and set them free.
Elizabeth David, the British food writer, was renowned for being a cookbook author in the latter camp (the American chef Anne Rosenzweig once said of David's writing: "Recipes were not recipes; they were ideas").
More recently, there have been many other strong examples of the approach.
Among contemporary books, Shirley King's "Fish: The Basics" comes to mind for its willingness to give direction and then trust the cook to do something with it.


Six in Sixth Deep-Six the Drowning Mets
The six stayed up on the scoreboard, fat and forever.
The six -- the number of runs the Astros scored in the sixth inning to win, 7-5 -- was the latest product of Mets disaster, the most recent evidence that there is not much more to their 1993 season but the most joyless or ludicrous sorts of calculations.
Can the Mets lose 100 games?
Can the club be mathematically eliminated by the All-Star Game break?
When exactly will the parade of promotions from the minors begin?
How many hours are left before Manager Dallas Green resigns and goes to join his wife in Tibet?
Weakening in the Sixth
The Mets have specialized in provoking such fatalism.
Tonight's sixth inning was the heart of the latest darkness.
Bret Saberhagen, starting despite residual weakness after a bout with bronchitis, was nonetheless vulnerable in the sixth.
Steve Finley tripled to lead off and scored on a groundout.
The bases, momentarily cleared, were soon overpopulated and cleared again, a great migration of Astros that would transform a 5-2 lead to a 7-5 deficit.


Main Yeltsin Rival Bolts Constitution Conference
As a constitutional conference intended to chart Russia's political future opened today, the chairman of Russia's Parliament stormed out, accusing President Boris N. Yeltsin of pushing ahead with a new constitution that would move the country toward a dictatorship.
The departure of the chairman, Ruslan I. Khasbulatov, who was followed by about 50 other delegates, cast a pall over prospects for the smooth adoption of the country's first post-Communist constitution, an effort that Mr.
Yelstin described as "a most important watershed in the life in the Russian state."


Serbians Veer Closer to Their Extreme Edge
FOR Vojislav Seselj, it was a restrained performance.
Barely two days before, this Serbian extremist had the pleasure of watching two detested political rivals being ground into the dust.
One was the President of Yugoslavia, Dobrica Cosic, summarily dismissed by parliamentary intrigue that ended in a vote of no confidence.
The other was Vuk Draskovic, the wild-eyed opposition leader whose long hair and beard summoned up for many Yugoslavs the image of Jesus Christ, now prostrate in prison with injuries from police beatings and facing charges for having led a protest that turned violent.
So Mr.
Seselj (pronounced SHESH-el) was holding a press conference, his heavy frame squeezed behind a table in the headquarters of his Serbian Radical Party.
On the walls around him were the icons of the cause -- the Serbian tricolor, portraits of saints, a mystical canvas of a bedraggled Serbian soldier and, at center, a likeness stamped in brass of the World War II Chetnik leader, Draza Mihailovic.
Though the crowded room was as cramped as a coffin, he shouted replies in full voice: Serbia was under siege.
Her people were being demonized by the media.
No, he would never accept a peace plan with Lord Owen's signature.


Catered Affair
HIRING A CATERER IS more like finding a hairdresser than locating a plumber.
It means entering into a relationship with someone whose taste will reflect yours.
And when the occasion is as personal as a wedding, the choice of a caterer and the orchestration of the event become even more important.
Today, there are more caterers than ever, providing everything from a small dinner to a cocktail reception to an at-home wedding.
A caterer can merely provide the food, leaving the responsibility for equipment, serving and cleaning to the host, or arrange for bartenders and waiters.
For a fee, caterers will take charge of every detail -- the rental of tableware, tables, chairs, linens, tents and a dance floor.


Dinkins and Council Face Fiscal Maw's 300 Million Sharp Teeth
The sky was dark and menacing over Lower Manhattan yesterday, but it was no match for the gloom inside City Hall, where New York's political leaders worked behind closed doors to scale back the size of the municipal government by a hefty $300 million.
Cutting funds for valued services like day-care, summer school and homeless drop-in centers is never appealing to elected officials.
But Mayor David N. Dinkins, Council Speaker Peter F. Vallone and the 50 other members of the Council no doubt feel particularly vulnerable doing it now, just months before they will ask voters to re-elect them.

The Forbidden Books of Youth
What was the first "forbidden" book you read and what were the circumstances under which you read it?
The editors of the Book Review asked 14 men and women to share their secrets of fantasies inspired, expectations dashed, wisdom gained and the lonely knowledge that only comes in the dead of night with a flashlight in hand and a head under the covers.
Here are the responses.
Elmore Leonard
In the seventh or eighth grade a friend of mine who also read books told me that "Anthony Adverse," by Hervey Allen, had dirty parts in it; and I remember looking but don't recall if I found any.
It's not that I was forbidden to read the novel -- it was on the shelf at home, I think a Book-of-the-Month-Club selection -- but I did probably look through it on the sly, making the act feel forbidden.


Tribute to a 'Populist of the Highest Order'
WITH poetry, original dance compositions and emotional tributes, members of the world of modern dance recently honored the long and still active career of Bessie Schonberg, one of its revered leaders.
Gathered in a dance studio at Sarah Lawrence College here, the crowd of about 60 sometimes tearful alumni, dance professionals and academics watched as the studio -- in which Miss Schonberg often taught as the director of the college's dance department from 1938 to 1973 -- was officially named the Bessie Schonberg Dance Theater.


Bosnia Serbs Renew Attack on U.N. 'Safe Area' Town
Bosnian Serbs renewed shelling and infantry attacks on the United Nations-declared safe area of Gorazde today and aimed fierce artillery barrages against Gradacac, Gracanica and Brcko, the Sarajevo radio reported.
The towns lie along a corridor that links Serbia to Serb-held territory in Croatia and Bosnia.
United Nations officials here said the Bosnian Serbs continued to refuse to allow United Nations military monitors into Gorazde, where 60,000 people have been under Serbian attack for more than a week.

Groom Patrol
Weed, weed, weed, and thin, thin, thin.
These two chores are unfortunately the key to growing hefty plants that have enough nutrients and space to grow.
As you're weeding, keep an eye out for annuals that have self-seeded that you may want to save.
Last week, I found lots of dill and cleome, which I moved to other parts of the garden.
Some hardy annuals likely to seed themselves are calendula, bachelor's button, cosmos, nicotiana, larkspur and forget-me-nots.
So if you have them in the garden, don't cut off all their spent blossoms this summer.
Let some go to seed.
Then mulch the area before the ground freezes, and in the spring, see what comes up.

On Sunday; What's Humor To One Brings Pain to Another
NORA Weinerth is an advocate for the mentally ill, a co-founder of the New York-based National Stigma Clearinghouse.
Last fall she received complaints about Doug Marlette's Kudzu comic strip, and soon after issued a Stigma Busters Alert, accusing Mr.
Marlette of "flippant treatment of depression, euthanasia and suicide in over a dozen strips."
She has scored many stigma-busting coups.
She persuaded the John Deere company to stop ads on "the world's first schizophrenic lawn mower." She wrote, "Why is it that schizophrenia is fair game for comedians in a way that cancer, AIDS and drug addiction are not?" Clarion Car Audio killed its "A Lot of Good an Airbag Will Do You If You Go Insane" campaign.
Others capitulating include Nike sneakers, Wordstar software, Planters foods.


Swimming Pools and the Environment
HARDLY anything is more sybaritic than floating in a swimming pool 20 or 30 or even 40 yards from Long Island Sound, but since March 10 that pleasure has been sharply curtailed for waterfront residents of the village of Larchmont, the town and village of Mamaroneck and the city of Rye.
Under the State Department of Environmental Conservation's regulation of Coastal Erosion Hazard Areas, the construction of swimming pools on the grounds of houses in the Coastal Erosion Hazard Area of the four communities will no longer be possible.
"It is because pools, more than any other structures, will increase the erosion action, because pools are so heavy," said Patrick L. Ferracane, water-program specialist with the State Department of Environmental Conservation for Region 3 in Tarrytown, which includes Westchester.


Trustees Back Shift of Deans At Columbia
Columbia University's Board of Trustees yesterday approved an administrative shake-up that the university's incoming president said was his first step to eliminate the university's $15 million operating deficit and to establish stronger control over its sprawling arts and sciences faculty.
The new president, George E. Rupp, presented the changes, which include the replacement of three deans and a vice president, to the Columbia trustees at their quarterly meeting.
Mr.
Rupp, who is now the president of Rice University in Houston, made clear in an interview before the meeting that he was planning further restructuring after he succeeded Michael I. Sovern on July 1.


In Zaire, Leaders Still Prey on the Led
To the Editor:
Having lived in Kinshasa, Zaire, from 1989 through 1991, I follow your all-to-rare reporting from there with intense interest.
"In Zaire, Starvation Is Growing in a Wealthy Land" (news article, May 16) struck a nerve.
The observation that "acute food problems facing Zaire appear self-inflicted" risks pointing the finger in the wrong direction; self-inflicted and Government-inflicted are not the same, especially in a country where those in power are accountable to no one.
The overwhelming majority of Zairians have had virtually nothing to do with causing the problems they face daily.
The practice of blaming the victim is in this case, as in any case, inappropriate and destructive.


The Empty Embassies
Let's stipulate that President Clinton has a lot on his mind these days besides naming ambassadors.
Granted, too, that his choosing of ambassadors is complicated by a laudable desire to give more scope to women and minorities.
Add to this the cumbersome F.B.I. clearances that now include the Nannygate hurdle of possible prior employment of illegal domestics.
Even so, none of those factors can excuse the surfeit of empty embassies still sitting in many countries, some of vital importance to American foreign policy.
These vacancies attest to the indecision that afflicts a wobbling Presidency.


A Victorian Jewel That's Also a Mine for Musical Theater
WHEN the announcement was made to preserve rather than demolish the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam in 1959, Gov.
Abraham A. Ribicoff declared: "This to me is very important for the country's soul."
A whirl of musicales, soirees and benefits of all sorts, even plaster ripping parties, followed for the purpose of raising the $500,000 required to restore the many splendored showplace, then being used by the State Highway Department as a storage depot.
And for the four years it took to complete, the restoration of the four-story Opry House -- a frequent spelling at the time it was built in 1876 -- on the banks of the Connecticut River was the talk of eastern Connecticut.
Sightseers paid 50 cents for a tour of the work in progress on Saturdays between 2 and 4 P.M.
By varying accounts, about twice the amount needed for the restoration came in, and the reopening of Goodspeed, a victory for esthetics and for civilization, took place on June 18, 1963.
And the show that marked its rebirth in Victorian splendor was "Oh Lady! Lady!" by Jerome Kern.

NEW PLANS READY FOR SPACE STATION
The nine-year, $9 billion space-station program enters a crucial phase this week as the Clinton Administration ends a four-month bid to slim down the proposed outpost for orbiting astronauts while weighing full participation by the Russians.
The process of redesign, as full of zigs and zags as the beleaguered station program itself, has produced three alternatives, each progressively cheaper than the $31 billion, 350-foot design that the Clinton White House inherited from the Bush Administration.

1 Standard for All
To the Sports Editor:
If The Times's reports about Michael Jordan's gambling activities are correct, then the National Basketball Association should suspend Jordan for one year.
Bulls forward Horace Grant is right: We should not have one standard for Michael Jordan and a wholly different standard for everybody else.
A double standard communicates the message that, as long as you are a great player, you can do anything you want and get away with it.
By suspending Michael Jordan for gambling activities, the N.B.A. will safeguard the integrity and credibility of professional basketball and also send an important and much needed message about character.
HAVEN BRADFORD GOW Arlington Heights, Ill.


Cold Feet in the Senate
The weather outside the Capitol is warming up with the approach of summer.
But inside some Senate Democrats are getting cold feet about serious political reform.
The sticking point is public financing of elections.
Unless President Clinton and Senate Democrats who understand the public's disgust at the present system now stand firm, a critical component of reform could be lost.
The issue will be joined in earnest this week when the Senate resumes debate on Mr.
Clinton's proposed campaign finance reform.
It's a promising bill that would curb reliance on special interests and foster greater competition by establishing a system of spending limits and partial public financing for House and Senate campaigns.

Montreal Surges, Falters, Endures
In the City of Angels, early in overtime, "all hell seemed to break loose," according to Marty McSorley.
The Kings' defenseman was discussing how the Montreal Canadiens stormed the goal crease and scored to win the game, 4-3, on a goal by John LeClair and take a two-games-to-one lead in the Stanley Cup finals.
LeClair's first shot got by Kelly Hrudey, the Los Angeles goalie, but slithered wide of the post.
McSorley and his teammates went for the rebound.

LeClair kept whacking at the loose puck as a shriek rose from the throats of 16,005 Forum fans.

Adventures in Russia'a Far East
The loosening of travel restrictions to the Russian Far East has spawned a number of new adventure tours to places formerly closed to foreigners.
The destinations include the Kamchatka Peninsula, the strategic military area over which Korean Airlines Flight 007 flew before it was shot down by the Russians in 1983.
"Crossroads of Continents -- Remote Alaska and the Russian Far East Above the Arctic Circle," is an 11-day voyage aboard Clipper Adventure Cruises' 138-passenger World Discoverer, a ship built especially for navigation through ice-strewn waters.
The ship, which will follow 18th- and 19th-century exploration routes, departs Nome July 11, 21 and 31 and Aug. 10.
Stops in Russia include the whaling village of Novoye Chaplino, the town of Provideniya and Uelen, an isolated Chukchi village, the easternmost outpost of the Russian continent.
Guides will be on hand to identify wildlife, such as Pacific walruses, whales and polar bears, and to lecture on Russian, Aleut, Chukchi and Yuit culture and history.
Cost per person, double occupancy, is $3,500 to $5,200 and does not include air fare.
Information: Clipper Adventure Cruises, 7711 Bonhomme Avenue, St.
Louis, Mo. 63105; (800) 325-0010.

New Life for An Old Rivalry?
AFTER 60 years of vying for dominance in 35-millimeter photography, Leica and Contax, the German camera makers, may be poised to enter another round.
The stage has been set with the introduction of the newest Contax single-lens-reflex camera, the ST.
The ST has some features that just may stir the competitive spirit at Leica.
One is a ceramic pressure plate, which the company says keeps the film flatter than the plate in any other camera and does not react to temperature or humidity.
And all the analogue dials on top of the camera can be lighted at night with the push of a button; the light goes off after 16 seconds, avoiding battery drain.

Alfresco Dining, Mediterranean Style
WHEN Ed Brown, who is the executive chef at Tropica, the Manhattan seafood restaurant, catered the wedding last year of Pierre Franey's son Jacques to Trish Cancalosi on the beach in East Hampton, he prepared a spectacular outdoor meal for 200 guests.
But instead of making stews and casseroles to be reheated, everything was either cooked on the spot or served at room temperature.
To do this, he brought along a convoy of chefs from Manhattan who had worked through the night to prepare the meal.
"I went for the Provencal style," he said.
"I chose the sort of things you see on the Cote d'Azur, in Tuscany or Tunisia: roast vegetables, grains, herbs, olives, oil, garlic -- boldly, highly seasoned food." While an army of chefs may have been needed to put together the food for the wedding, the individual dishes are simple enough for the home cook to prepare with ease.
They are great for a summer picnic or outdoor meal on a warm day.


'Orlando,' Like Its Hero(ine), Is One for the Ages
"Do not fade, do not wither, do not grow old," the aged Queen Elizabeth I tells the young nobleman Orlando, making this fantastic request the condition on which she gives him a magnificent estate.
So the writer and director Sally Potter sets her androgynous hero off through 400 years of history and sexual politics, barely pausing to change Orlando from man to woman along the way.
As a 17th-century man, a lovelorn Orlando condemns "the treachery of women"; in the 18th century he is so appalled by the macho code of war that he goes to sleep as one sex and wakes up another; and as a 19th-century woman, Orlando learns that she will lose the estate unless she has a son.
Like the 1928 Virginia Woolf novel on which it is based, the screen version of "Orlando" is a delicious fantasy rooted in a rigorous sense of social history.


Q and A
A Noisy Restaurant Question: A newly opened brasserie-style restaurant is located directly below my rent-stabilized apartment.
The owners have installed a bare concrete floor, which causes the shrill sound of moving tables and chairs by customers or cleaning crews to travel through the cement columns into my apartment day and night.
Three months of correspondence with our common landlord has produced no results.
Is there anything I can do? . . .
Paul W. Lowry, Manhattan Answer: Yes.
Call the city's Department of Environmental Protection hot line (718) 699-9811.
The telephone number is answered 24 hours a day and is designed to receive complaints about noise, odors, water, asbestos or hazardous materials.


CAPITAL GHOSTS
As a longtime (but not native) resident of the Washington area, I was greatly moved by Maureen Dowd's Endpaper "Capital Ghosts" (Life and Times, May 9).
The rest of this country seems to believe that Washington is composed of transient Government officials who come and go with the passage of each administration.
The news media tend to further exacerbate that image by constant references to the thinking "inside the Beltway," as if those of us who reside within that ring are somehow different from the rest of the country.
Maureen Dowd's thoughtful essay reminds us that Washington, along with its Maryland and Virginia suburbs, is filled with communities of ordinary and extraordinary people.
It is where my children are growing up and putting down roots.
I only hope that their memories will be as dear to them as Dowd's are to her.

If the Polo Is Free, Are Rates Headed Up?
ARE banks starting to get more friendly?
Do they actually want to lend more money, and to attract the deposits needed to make those loans?
If the answer to those questions is yes, it represents a big change from the situation that prevailed over the past couple of years.
In the wake of loan debacles, banks decided to get smaller.
Would-be borrowers found credit standards were tougher, and the interest rates offered to depositors tumbled.


Furniture With Grit, a la Hamptons
WITH Bottleworks Marketplace, a new store in Sag Harbor, L.I., that sells furniture made of antique barn wood, the carpenters Stephen and William Spooner may have hit the marketing nail right on the head.
The two brothers, who specialize in relocating 18th- and 19th-century post-and-beam barns and houses on Long Island and in Connecticut, recycle leftover barn wood into unpretentiously rustic furnishings, including cupboards, tables, armoires and chests.
There is also an unerring eye at work in the selection of accessories and other antiques, like birdhouses ($40 to $65), wrought-iron candlesticks ($20 to 40 each) and wicker furniture ($1,200 for a graceful sofa and two matching chairs).

Clinton Myth of Nonideological Politics Stumbles
The wreck of Lani Guinier may mark the end of a central myth of the Clinton Administration.
The myth was that President Clinton would painlessly lead America into a post-cold-war age of New Politics, in which the old divisive "false choices" of left versus right would merge into a new middle ground of happy consensus.


The Quest to Conserve Electrical Power
It is unfortunate that "Lilco Ends a Homeowners' Rebate Program"  [ May 16 ]  further confuses a complicated issue.
There are two central issues facing those of us active in the fields of energy analysis, conservation and demand-side management.
The first concerns are the quality, cost-effectiveness and long-term viability of utility demand-side management programs.
The second is the methodology that the New York State Public Service Commission uses to allow Lilco and other New York State utilities to recover energy-conservation costs through the rate base.
And while these two issues affect each other, it is important to make distinctions between the two.

No Need to Celebrate A 'Record High' Dow
To the Editor:
"Stocks and Bonds Surge; Dow Hits 3,500" (Business Day, May 20) reports a "record high." I suspect that many readers not familiar with finance or economics would, quite sensibly, take this to mean that the dollar value of the Dow on May 19 had greater buying power than at any previous closing.
Such readers would be justified in feeling confusion when record highs coincide with decreasing buying power (as they often do, because inflation increases the price of both stocks and groceries).
In other words, a Dow of 3,000 when an automobile costs $12,000 is not in any meaningful sense as high as a Dow of 1,000 when an automobile costs $3,000.


MORE PEOPLE VIEW CLINTON AS LIBERAL AS HE SEEKS CENTER
As President Clinton struggles to return to the centrist policies that won the election, an increased number of Americans view him as a liberal, and many say his economic plan relies too heavily on raising taxes and would do little to help the economy, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
Most Americans do not appear convinced by Mr.
Clinton's repeated efforts to show that his economic remedies will place a heavier burden on rich people than on the middle class.
And they have grown increasingly skeptical about the fairness and effectiveness of the plan.


Beijing Bans Trade in Rhino and Tiger Parts
China has published a ban on the trade of rhinoceros horns and tiger bones, coveted substances that have been essential to an enormously lucrative business in traditional Chinese medicines.
Tiger bones and rhinoceros horns have a special cachet among many Chinese, who believe that these exotic ingredients function as tonics that can heal and invigorate the body.
The ban, if enforced, will be deeply resented by many but will help preserve the animals from poachers.

Fire Islanders Try To Fill the Breach
Fire Islanders have undertaken the responsibility to do as much as possible to conserve and protect the Fire Island barrier island.
Year after year we have invested hundreds of thousands of homeowner private dollars and thousands of person-hours to build and rebuild dunes.
We have an enlightened self-interest to protect our own homes as well as the thousands of homes on the northern side of Great South Bay, which would suffer constant storm flooding should a new inlet be riven through Fire Island.


U.N. Starts Plans for Bosnia Force Tomorrow
Senior peacekeeping officials, in a special meeting on Monday, will ask the five co-sponsors of a new Security Council resolution on Bosnia what troops, weapons and money they will provide to protect the designated safe havens for Muslims.
The resolution, passed on Friday, would require as many as 25,000 troops backed by artillery and attack helicopters, senior United Nations officials said.
That preliminary estimate is far higher than the force of 5,000 to 10,000 that some diplomats had said might be sufficient.


Signs of Blast Fading, but Tremors Remain
The spacious elevators, stuffed with executives and camera-toting tourists, are once again gliding like zippers up and down the towers of the World Trade Center.
New windows have replaced shattered ones.
Fresh paint covers smoke-stained walls.
Except for a few posters referring to "repairs" and a phalanx of guards checking new identification cards, there are few signs that just three months ago, a huge explosion ripped through the trade center's underground garage, killing six people and sending tens of thousands scrambling down smoke-filled stairwells to safety.


Restaurateur on a Frogmobile
There's a new, youthful presence at La Grenouille, and it's not a result of plastic surgery.
In January, the 30-year-old French restaurant on East 52d Street lost its longtime manager, Charles Masson, 38, who was responsible for La Grenouille's inspired flower arrangements, among other things.
Mr.
Masson, whose father founded the restaurant, now works with Robert Isabell, the floral designer.

Krone Winds Up First In More Ways Than 1
Julie Krone was eavesdropping yesterday and didn't like what she heard.
She drew herself to her 4 feet 10 1/2 inches and, in that squeaky voice that makes 1,200-pound horses run so fast, admonished Scotty Shulhofer.
"What year is this?" she said.
"Sixty-something or '93?"
She was kidding, more or less.
For Schulhofer had just admitted that he had once been against women jockeys.


BOLIVIA TO VOTE FOR ITS PRESIDENT
Bolivians vote for a new President on Sunday, no small feat for a country that has a history of more military coups and dictatorships than any other in Latin America.
If, as predicted, the election goes off without violence and significant fraud, it will usher in the fourth consecutive civilian government since 1982, a remarkable period of stability for this nation.
From 1964 to 1982, it had 16 governments, 14 of them military.


Whale Watching
To the Editor: The Q &amp; A column on May 16 contained a request for information on whale watching, which was followed by a long list of ports, including the Okeanos Foundation sailings from Hampton Bays, L.I.
Two years ago my boyfriend and I went on a whale-watching trip with this organization after having read about it in The Times.
We took Dramamine before boarding, anticipating that there might be some queasiness, but we were never so sick in our lives.
More than 75 percent of the passengers were just as sick.
Old people, young people and kids were vomiting profusely almost the entire time.


An Appreciation Of 'Mothers' on Stage
To read Alvin Klein's recent review of "Mothers," at the Crossroads Theater, made me believe that the play was a dull, outlandish and obvious vehicle -- a play that not only could but should be overlooked.
How far from the truth (both dramatic and emotional) can you get?
With trepidation, I went to see the production.
Not only did I see it, I felt it as well.
My own emotions as a human being were stirred.
As a theater person, I may be a bit more critical than others, but the performances, the play, the interplay of past and present, of ritual and reality, of customs both East and West, thoroughly overtook me.

Across the Computer Divide, The Nerds Face the Dummies
"DOS for Dummies," a how-to guide for using the software that runs most personal computers, seems to violate a time-honored tenet of business: never insult the customer.
Several publishers rejected the book, and once it was published leading bookstore chains initially declined to stock it.
The first printing was a cautious 7,500 copies, and expectations were modest.


The 'Busters' Are Bored
To the Editor:
I have noted with bemusement that rare is the Styles section that does not contain an article about grunge or raves.
The boomer fascination with this supposed trend of the baby-bust generation far exceeds any interest which most of us "busters" have in it, and as a result, it has received attention far out of proportion to its actual popularity.


Rockies' Pitchers Serve Up Feasts for Batters
It had to appear as simple to the architects of expansion as it did to the architects of the Clinton campaign.
The pitching, stupid.
Concentrate on that and that alone and you have a chance to be a representative major league club.
Fail to put some semblance of a foundation together, fail to build from the mound out, and you have the Colorado Rockies.


'Pippen Flamboyant' Sends Bulls Into Finals
Perhaps now the word soft, that four-letter word in Scottie Pippen's business, will be set aside forever.
A year removed from his ankle miseries and Xavier McDaniel's wild-eyed pursuit that limited Pippen in the playoff series against the Knicks and raised persistent doubts about his game, he has lifted the Bulls to the championship series in a way that only an elite player can.


The Quixotic Days and Nights of Jay Tarses
In conversation, Jay Tarses is a perfectly affable fellow.
He is delighted to talk about the last television series he created, "The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd," which enjoyed a long and happy run on cable.
He speaks of how he yearns to direct a feature film, and the enjoyment of writing and rewriting his first play.
But eventually the subject gets around to the networks -- specifically NBC, which has just put his latest comedy series on the air after warehousing it for six months.
"I don't like these people," he said.
"They don't treat people right. They don't treat their suppliers with any kind of camaraderie or respect. It's an adversarial relationship -- at least it is with me."

Update; Cleanup of Abandoned Tires Beginning in New York City
New York is beginning a $200,000 program to collect and dispose of thousands of abandoned tires as mounds of them continue to grow in some of the city's neglected neighborhoods.
Called the Waste Tire Management Program, the plan calls for the city's Departments of Transportation and Sanitation to collect junk tires from some 300 illegal dump sites in the five boroughs.
Beginning in mid-July, about 150,000 tires are expected to be collected and placed on four city-owned lots for disposal by an outside vendor, city officials said.

DAN GOOKIN, author of "DOS for Dummies," on computer experts.  [ 32:3. ]


Russia Sets Out on a Pitted Road to a New Constitution
RUSSIA'S attempts to write a new constitution offer a humbling lesson on the limitations of history as guide.
Many a nation has traveled this road on the way to democracy; even Russia itself tried once before, albeit unsuccessfully.
Yet in the unending struggles between legislators and president, between Moscow and the provinces, Russia seems doomed to retrace the full route, from the very start and over every obstacle, stumbling every step of the way.


A Fugitive's Tale Sheds Light On China Today
One of the astonishing facts of the Tiananmen Square protest in Beijing four years ago was that 8 of the 21 students on the security police's most-wanted list managed to evade arrest and eventually to escape to the West.
It happens, moreover, that China, at least until recently, has had a security apparatus so ruthlessly efficient that escape was hardly thought of, much less attempted.
And so, the question is: How did the students do it?
At least a partial answer is provided by "Escape From China," a 57-minute documentary by Iris F. Kung, the pseudonym of a Chinese television reporter now living in the United States.
The film, which will be shown Friday and Saturday at the Anthology Film Archives, tells the story of 25-year-old Zhang Boli, one of the most prominent of the student leaders and the person who hid in China longer than any other of the hunted dissidents.


Wish Lists
AH, THE BRIDAL REGISTRY!
THE handsome Royal Doulton, the delicate Baccarat, the gleaming Buccellati.
Not to mention the ride-on lawn mower, the composting toilet, the boxed set of compact disks and the down payment on a house.
Move over, Tiffany &amp; Company.
Make room for the Home Depot.
Social changes are playing havoc not only with the wedding ceremony and the institution of marriage itself but with the traditional bridal registry.
Once used as a way for guests to discreetly ascertain the bride's chosen china and silver patterns, the bridal registry now serves as a wish list encompassing everything from garbage cans to fine wines.


POSTINGS: Regional Planning Conference; Workshops on Making the Area Work
Anyone who believes that "united we stand" is as applicable to states as to people might enjoy the Regional Plan Association's day-long conference this Tuesday.
The association, which is dedicated to getting New York, New Jersey and Connecticut to set joint policies that can improve the quality of life in all three states, says that by day's end a blueprint will have emerged for turning this area into "The Region That Works."
The meeting will offer a series of workshops dealing with such subjects as rebuilding and expanding the region's infrastructure, protecting its environmental resources, training its labor, and ways of wooing companies -- and jobs -- to the area.


A Rustic Place To Hang a Hat
You can search for original furniture till the cows come home.
Here it is in the form of what its maker, Stephen Spooner, calls a gentleman's cupboard.
The piece has the chipped-paint door of a rural outhouse, dimensions like those of a phone booth and a peaked shingle roof suggestive of a fractured fairy tale.

MAY 30-JUNE 5: A.T.&amp;T., Phone Europe; For Long-Distance Giants, All the World's an Area Code
MCI Communications launched competition in the American long-distance telephone industry more than a decade ago when it took on the old Bell System.
This week, MCI ushered in a new round of competition in global telephone markets when it teamed up with British Telecommunications to provide one-stop-shopping for multinational corporations that link their far-flung offices over private networks that ring the world.

Bringing Dinos Back to Life
WHAT EXACTLY ARE YOU seeing when a triceratops or a velociraptor appears on screen in "Jurassic Park"?
For close-ups, the film makers often used full-size robots by the model-maker Stan Winston.
When the dinosaurs are in motion, however, viewers will probably be looking at computer animation.
The animation took place at Industrial Light and Magic, the California special-effects house.
The company, which has also handled special effects for "The Abyss" and "Terminator 2: Judgment Day," used the dinosaur robots designed by Mr.
Winston (such as the seven-foot velociraptors pictured here) as guides.
The animation alone took 18 months.
Meanwhile, other technicians blocked out the actions of the invisible dinosaurs on the movie set.

Public &amp; Private; Political Illiteracy
There's a certain kind of conversation you have from time to time at parties in New York about a new book.
The word "banal" sometimes rears its by-now banal head; you say "underedited," I say "derivative." The conversation goes around and around various literary criticisms, and by the time it moves on one thing is clear: no one read the book, we just read the reviews.
A variation on those conversations has taken place in Washington over the last month about the past opinions of an accomplished and ill-treated woman named Lani Guinier.


Commercial Property: Bryant Park; Once Anathema, Now a Midtown Marketing Tool
CONVENTIONAL wisdom says nobody is getting higher rents for commercial space today than they did a few years ago.
But don't tell that to Tom Kelly.
Mr.
Kelly is a senior vice president of Mountain Development Corporation, which owns the Beaux Arts, the landmarked office building at the southeast corner of 40th Street and Avenue of the Americas.
Until a year or so ago, four of the building's 10 floors were empty and, at asking prices of about $19 a foot, tenants were barely nibbling.


Hikers Seek New Trails to Conquer
PEOPLE collect all kinds of things from Old Master paintings to barbed wire, from eggs to baseball cards.
In climbing and hiking circles mountains are collected as assiduously as are first editions by bibliophiles.
The sport is known as peak bagging.
There is nothing tangible to show for it, just the satisfaction of having reached the summit and possibly the opportunity to join an organization of climbers of similar achievement.


Aspin Meets Russian in Bid to Take Ukraine's A-Arms
Stepping up the American campaign to persuade the Ukrainians to give up their nuclear weapons, Defense Secretary Les Aspin came here today to discuss with Russia a new plan to dismantle Ukraine's nuclear missiles and place their warheads under international supervision.
Mr.
Aspin met with the Russian Defense Minister, Gen.
Pavel S. Grachev.
The plan is intended to resolve a Russian-Ukrainian dispute on how to deal with the warheads that would be removed from Ukraine's missiles if Ukraine gave up its nuclear arms.


In Sarajevo, War Also Means Battles of the Sexes
With her food store and home reduced to rubble, her city besieged and her nation uprooted, Jasna Delalic picked the darkest days of Bosnia's war to become a single mother.
Despite constant shelling, food and water queues and deep uncertainty about the future, Mrs.
Delalic has filed for divorce from her 33-year-old husband because he refused to fight the nationalist Serbs attacking Sarajevo.
"I hate cowards," said the jobless, 30-year-old Muslim woman, who now lugs her food-aid packages back to a one-room apartment she shares with her two grade-school-age daughters and another single woman.
"He was supposed to stay on the front line, but he wounded himself in the leg with an automatic."


Their Prince Is Back; Cambodians Are Baffled
AFTER two decades mostly removed from the gilded stage of Southeast Asian politics, one of its last great showmen, Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, is making ready his final performance.
Cambodians are praying that he triumphs.
Once a king.
Always a politician.
Deal maker.
Film maker.
Author.
Linguist.
Bon vivant.
His apparently imminent return to power in Cambodia is the best possible news for those who like their politics as theater.


G.O.P. IN VIRGINIA PICKS FALL SLATE
Virginia Republicans, always among the most conservative in the country, moved even further to the right today as they nominated candidates for Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General in this fall's election.
Meeting in a convention here, 13,000 party delegates chose former Representative George Allen for the top spot on the ticket, then picked Mike Farris, a northern Virginia lawyer, for the Lieutenant Governor's slot.


EX-MIAMI OFFICER WANTS JOB BACK
To the dismay of local civil rights groups, a Hispanic policeman convicted here of killing two young black men, but then acquitted on the same charges last week in a second trial in Orlando, is seeking to return to active duty.
In his only interview since his acquittal, the officer, William Lozano, told a Spanish-language television station here that he would request reinstatement to active duty, which, if successful, would enable him to recover lost wages.
The 33-year-old police officer, born in Colombia, was relieved of duty without pay after being convicted of manslaughter in Miami in 1989, but the verdict was overturned in 1991 when a panel of judges ruled that jurors may have feared an outbreak of racial violence if they acquitted Mr.
Lozano.
He was acquitted by a jury in Orlando on May 28 after a three-week trial.


Dollar Gains In Finland
American visitors to Finland this year will find many prices dramatically lower than two years ago, thanks to a sharp drop in the value of the Finnish currency and a recession in that country.
According to a study conducted at the end of 1992 by Suomen Gallup Oy, a Finnish polling organization, which compared the prices for such staples as hotel rooms and a McDonald's Big Mac in 12 Western European capitals, Helsinki fell below the median on all types of lodging and most restaurant purchases, as well as train travel and airline tickets.
Exceptions included taxi fares, car rental and food bought at a grocery.

It's Science Against Nature's Cruel Imagination
COULD a new disease have arisen on Navajo land?
And, if so, is it going to spread as cholera has through South America, or will it be contained as the original outbreak of Legionnaire's disease was in a Philadelphia hotel?
Through the past week, a mysterious illness had befallen at least 19 people living on or near the Navajo Reservation, which sprawls across the northeastern corner of Arizona into New Mexico and Utah.
It begins with flu-like symptoms but rapidly progresses to respiratory distress.
The victims' lungs fill with fluid, they cannot get enough oxygen into their blood and they suffocate.
On Friday, health officials said that the illness may be caused by a virus linked to rodents and their droppings.


Orff: Two Second Thoughts
If ever a composer could be said to have fallen out of favor, it is Carl Orff.
His flamboyant scenic cantata "Carmina Burana" is occasionally performed on pops programs or by ballet companies.
His educational ideas, usually adulterated by the Kodaly method or another pedagogical approach, are still applied in schools.
But of the considerable breadth of his achievement, there is little representation.
So the budget reissue of the sole studio recording of Orff's quasi-opera "Antigonae" (Deutsche Grammophon 437 721-2; three CD's) is of particular interest.
Now available by import and set for American release later this year, it can be profitably compared with a newly released historical album of the 1949 world premiere at the Salzburg Festival (Stradivarius STR 10060; two CD's).

Average Americans, Given the Facts, Understand Tax Increases
To the Editor:
"The American people want reductions in spending before any increase in taxes," say Republicans and conservative Democrats in Congress.
Doubtless, most Americans, asked "Do you want your taxes raised?", will answer no.
But ask: "Do you want cuts in Social Security, Medicare and other entitlements? To have no money for police, for fixing roads, education and research? To have the United States sink to mediocrity, with the good life for only the wealthy?" The answer would also be no.
By all indications, it isn't possible to pay no more in taxes, or to reduce nonmilitary public expenditure, and still have a country with first-rate social institutions.
The last 12 years of conservative claims that these things can coexist by cutting the fat out of our Government have been refuted by a quadrupling of the national debt in that period.
After 12 years of trying, conservative fat cutters found little waste, but put a lot of worthwhile activities in a state of chronic malnourishment, which will cost us a lot more than what we save by starving our institutions.
The cost of the savings and loan bailout is the most spectacular result.


'Nunsense II' Stays Close to the Original
SEQUELS to films like "Rocky" or "Alien" are commonplace, and on occasion the subsequent I's, II's and III's are as good, even sometimes better, as the original.
In theater, however, the sequel syndrome has never caught on.
It is difficult to reassemble a creative team, and the costs involved in producing a new version of an old story are as prohibitive as staging an original.
Plus the specter of major flop sequels like "Annie II" and "Bring Back Birdie" hovers over the offices of wary angels.


Chinese Jade, Long Entombed, Comes To Vivid Life
Copper-colored jade? pink, brown, black and gray jade?
Jade in the usual colors of milky white or spinach green is virtually absent from the exhibition "Chinese Archaic Jades and Bronzes," at the Manhattan gallery of J. J. Lally and Company, through June.
And the works on display are so minimal in decoration and form that they seem carved of a different material than the elaborately chiseled jades of the Ming dynasty and beyond.


Delta Air Awards For Gay Partners
Delta Air Lines has changed the rules of its frequent flier program to make it easier for legally certified gay partners to transfer awards to each other.
Until now, Delta had allowed its frequent flier customers to transfer their awards -- typically tickets earned by flying a designated number of miles -- only to family members, which Delta defines as spouse, child, parent, siblings, grandparent, grandchild, in-laws, step children and step-siblings. .
Of the seven major domestic carriers, Delta, along with T.W.A., had the most restrictive policies regarding award transfers.
The other five -- USAir, United, American, Northwest and Continental -- allow frequent fliers to assign their awards to anyone they choose, regardless of relationship.

Alfresco Dining, Mediterranean Style
WHEN Ed Brown, who is the executive chef at Tropica, the Manhattan seafood restaurant, catered the wedding last year of Pierre Franey's son Jacques to Trish Cancalosi on the beach in East Hampton, he prepared a spectacular outdoor meal for 200 guests.
But instead of making stews and casseroles to be reheated, everything was either cooked on the spot or served at room temperature.
To do this, he brought along a convoy of chefs from Manhattan who had worked through the night to prepare the meal.
"I went for the Provencal style," he said.
"I chose the sort of things you see on the Cote d'Azur, in Tuscany or Tunisia: roast vegetables, grains, herbs, olives, oil, garlic -- boldly, highly seasoned food." While an army of chefs may have been needed to put together the food for the wedding, the individual dishes are simple enough for the home cook to prepare with ease.
They are great for a summer picnic or outdoor meal on a warm day.

65 Vertical Feet South of the Border
Pursuing drug traffickers wanted in the killing of the Archbishop of Guadalajara, the Mexican police stumbled onto a startling discovery last week: a sophisticated tunnel that was being snaked under the border for smuggling cocaine into California.
The sandstone tunnel, a quarter-mile long, is 65 feet underground, air conditioned, well-lighted and reinforced with timbers and concrete.
It begins under the floor of a Tijuana warehouse and, probably 80 percent complete, runs to the outskirts of San Diego.

My Son, The Rocket
HOW do you solve a problem like David Leslie?
You can't really blame the downtown "stunt artist," who also refers to himself as an "impact addict," for not telling his parents about his performance pieces.
Whose parents, after all, would want to hear about how their son flew himself, in a homemade rocket, over a mountain of watermelons on Broome Street in 1985?
Whose parents would want to hear how their son "exploded himself" as a human firecracker on the streets of Chinatown in 1986, or about the fight he staged with Riddick Bowe, now the heavyweight champion, on the Staten Island Ferry in 1987?


Cards for Calls On the Road
THE telephone debit card is coming to the United States.
This card, which in France and Japan provides almost the only way to operate a pay phone, is creeping into, rather than exploding on, the United States market.
But with the continuing activity of shoulder surfers, thieves who learn your telephone charge card number while you are using a pay phone and run up big bills with it, debit cards for use in the United States have appeal for people on the road.
The obvious drawback is that you pay in advance, but if you lose the card, or its numbers are copied by a thief, all you lose is the value remaining on the card.
With the camp season upon us, the phone debit card may also look worthwhile to parents who want to give children a way to call from anyplace to anyplace, not just collect to home, but do not want their credit card numbers drifting around.

Challenge of Replacing Old Foundation Sills
OWNERS of older, neglected or poorly built houses and outbuildings, especially in rural or wet locations, often face the problem of replacing decayed foundation sills, the horizontal beams separating the framing of the building from the foundation walls.
Replacing the sills is seldom a job for amateurs, but doing so on a detached garage, shed or small barn makes a challenging, if strenuous, project.
Two helpful books before before starting the job are "Renovating Old Houses" by George Nash (Taunton Press, 1992) and "Renovation: A Complete Guide" by Michael W. Litchfield (Prentice Hall, 1991).
A useful article on sills was in The Journal of Light Construction in October.
The magazine may be available in libraries, or readers can call (802) 434-4747.
