Learning More About Learning Disabilities
I want to commend the article ("What 'Learning Disability' Means," May 30) and Beryl Kaufman for further informing the public about learning disabilities.
Because those individuals with learning disabilities are of at least average intelligence, it should be emphasized that they can learn as well as their average intelligent peers and should be given every opportunity to do so.
We all have different learning styles.
Each of us uses a variety of strategies with which we receive, store and retrieve information in order to learn about and evaluate our environment.


ART
Opening Today
THE JEWISH MUSEUM, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, Manhattan.
After a two-and-a-half-year hiatus, during which the facade of its 1908 landmark building, the Warburg Mansion, was ingeniously cloned and its internal space nearly doubled, the Jewish Museum reopens today in expanded and renovated quarters.
Hours: Sundays, Mondays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Tuesdays, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.
Closed Fridays and Saturdays.
Admission: $6; $4 for students and the elderly.
Information: (212) 423-3200.
"ELIJAH PIERCE: WOODCARVER," the Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street.
Observing the centenary of Pierce's birth, this is a celebration of the 60-year career of one of America's premier self-taught artists, who specialized in carved and painted wood reliefs.
Through Aug. 22.
Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 6 P.M.; closed Mondays and Tuesdays.
Admission: $5 for adults; $3 for students and the elderly; $1 for children under 12.
Information: (212) 864-4500.
Continuing
"JOHN HEARTFIELD: PHOTOMONTAGES," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan.
A Berlin Dadaist who understood the threat of Nazism from the very beginning, John Heartfield (1891-1968) helped invent photomontage and used it to fight for Germany's consciousness and soul.
His bitterly satirical, passionately clearsighted and brilliantly composed images, which appeared on book covers and left-wing magazines, are among this century's greatest examples of political art.
This exhibition is the first full-scale survey of Heartfield's achievement in the United States.
Through July 6.
Also at the Modern: "LATIN AMERICAN ARTISTS OF THE 20TH CENTURY." The largest survey of modern Latin American art ever assembled, this crowded show offers an unfocussed tip-of-the-iceberg view that is outmoded and patronizing.
It's first half, which includes early modernists like Diego Rivera and Joaquin Torres-Garcia, is passingly good; its second, a disaster that gives only glimpses of the strength of contemporary Latin American art.
Through Sept. 7.
Hours: Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Fridays through Tuesdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; closed Wednesdays.
Admission: $7.50; $4.50 for students and the elderly; free for children under 16; Thursdays, 5 P.M. to 7 P.M.
"pay what you wish." Information: (212) 708-9480.
"SPLENDID LEGACY: THE HAVEMEYER COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, Manhattan.
Call it an in-house blockbuster, a museum-within-a-museum or full disclosure.
This show presents the cornucopia of paintings, sculptures, drawings, prints and decorative objects that the American sugar baron H. O. Havemeyer and his prescient wife, Louisine, gave the Metropolitan in the decades around the turn of the century.
From Rembrandt and El Greco to numerous works by Courbet, Degas, Cezanne and the Impressionists, from Japanese screens and Chinese vases to Islamic ceramics, it is a staggering exhibition.
It tells a tale of esthetic passion, opulent living and tremendous public spirit, while also outlining much of the history of art in fine style.
Through June 20.
Also at the Metropolitan: "THE WAKING DREAM: PHOTOGRAPHY'S FIRST CENTURY." The invention of photography enabled the world to know itself in a new way, and that new knowledge illuminates this astounding exhibition.
With 253 often rare, usually breathtaking images from the Gilman Paper Company Collection, the show begins with some of the first photographs ever made, from England and France in the early 1840's, and ends with photography's artistic coming of age in the first decades of the 20th century.
It is a compelling story, in which technical invention goes hand in hand with the will to document and the desire to create.
Through July 4.
Also at the Metropolitan: DRAWINGS FROM THE J. PAUL GETTY MUSEUM.
The youngest major-league collection of Old Master drawings is little more than a decade old and relatively small by European standards.
But the 130 works in this exhibition, which range from Raphael to van Gogh, suggest that what it lacks in quantity and longevity, it more than makes up in quality.
Through Aug. 8.
Hours: Sundays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; closed Mondays.
Admission: $6; $3 for the students and the elderly .
Information: (212) 535-7710.
"CZECH CUBISM: ARCHITECTURE AND DESIGN," Cooper-Hewitt National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street, Manhattan.
The invention of Cubism set off artistic aftershocks all over Europe, most fantastically in Czechoslovakia, where its effects were strongest in the applied arts, not the fine arts.
This exhibition of more than 100 drawings and objects created from 1910 to 1925 examines the flourishing of what might be called a Cubism of everyday life; it includes furniture, ceramics and metalwork as well as architectural renderings of the Cubist buildings of Prague.
Through July 25.
Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 9 P.M.; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays noon to 5 P.M.
Suggested contribution: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free on Tuesdays after 5 P.M.
Information: (212) 860-6898.
"A GREAT LEGACY: MORGAN COLLECTIONS, 1913-1943," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Murray Hill.
In the 30 years between J. P. Morgan Sr.'s death and his own, J. P. Morgan Jr. continued to add to the collection that his famous father had so grandly begun, making important acquisitions and opening the library to the public in 1924.
This exhibition of more than 300 works features illuminated manuscripts, rare printed books and autographed manuscripts; it is the first comprehensive display of the younger Morgan's collecting achievement.
Through Aug. 15.
Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M.; closed Mondays.
Suggested contribution: $5; $3 for students and the elderly.
Information: (212) 685-0008.
"SECRECY: AFRICAN ART THAT CONCEALS AND REVEALS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo.
The inaugural exhibition of this renamed and relocated museum, formerly at 54 East 68th Street, includes nearly 100 extraordinary artworks from sub-Saharan Africa: masks, figures, textiles, architectural fragments and reliquary objects.
It takes visual power for granted to examine social power, placing innovative emphasis on the objects' ritual uses and meanings and on the sacred, secret knowledge often encoded in their patterns and forms.
Through Aug. 22.
Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays and Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.
Closed Mondays and Tuesdays.
Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly.
Information: (212) 966-1313.
"BOB BISHOP: A LIFE IN AMERICAN FOLK ART," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, at 65th Street, Manhattan.
A tribute to Robert Bishop, who died last year after serving as director of the museum from 1977 to 1991, this exhibition commemorates his impact on both the museum's collection and the definition of folk art itself.
Ranging from portraits by the 19th-century artist Ammi Philips to Shaker seed boxes, to contemporary folk art, it offers something for every taste, purist and otherwise.
Through Sept. 12.
Hours: daily except Mondays, 11:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M.
Suggested donation: $2.
Information: (212) 977-7298.
"GODS, GUARDIANS AND LOVERS: TEMPLE SCULPTURE FROM NORTH INDIA, A.D. 700-1200," the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, Manhattan.
Presenting 74 lavishly carved stone sculptures from the golden age of Hindu temple-building, this exhibition makes an unusual attempt to heighten their religious meaning by recreating a sense of their original architectural settings.
Through Aug. 15.

PAUL KLEE AT THE GUGGENHEIM, Guggenheim Museum SoHo, 575 Broadway, at Prince Street.

"HAND-PAINTED POP: AMERICAN ART IN TRANSITION, 1955-1962," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, Manhattan.
Before Pop artists started using the silk-screen process and other means of mechanical reproduction to scavenge images from mass culture, they did it by hand, often carrying over Abstract Expressionistic flourishes and asides from their immediate predecessors.
This exhibition will examine the transition between the two movements with 150 works by Jim Dine, Jasper Johns, Larry Rivers, Roy Lichtenstein, Wayne Thiebaud, Cy Twombly and others.

About 500 objects and documentary materials by some 40 artists, dating from 1962 to the present, trace the genesis and resiliency of this irreverent, anarchic art movement, which grew out of Dada and helped set the stage for Conceptual, performance and installation art.

Mediators Fly to Croatia To Broach Peace Options
Thwarted by continued fighting in Bosnia and Herzegovina and the threat of a new war in Croatia, international mediators unexpectedly flew to Zagreb today to discuss possible changes in their troubled peace plan with President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, officials familiar with the initiative said.
Although they refused to discuss the proposed changes in any detail, those officials said the mediators, Lord Owen and Thorvald Stoltenberg, were reviewing their plan for dividing Bosnia and Herzegovina into 10 largely autonomous provinces under a weak central government and considering changes that might effectively partition the country into separate regions of Serbs, Croats and Muslims instead.

Balanchine: Visions Without The Frills
Although George Balanchine was often choreographically unorthodox, few balletgoers would compare his art with modern dance.
Yet it's possible to do so, and not just because he and Martha Graham created "Episodes" in 1959.
That project was a pairing, rather than a collaboration: two independently choreographed works to music by Webern that were performed on the same program.
Balanchine, the familiar argument runs, was a product of ballet's most classical traditions.
But this stance overlooks the questing spirit that led him to what was known from the 1920's onward as Absolute Dance.
Among the milestones along Balanchine's journey toward that form are "Apollo" (1928), "Concerto Barocco" (1941), "Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2" (1941) and "The Four Temperaments" (1946).
All four have been splendidly danced by the New York City Ballet during its current "Balanchine Celebration." To see these works at the New York State Theater and to compare them with the way they were said to look when new is to gain insights into how Balanchine developed his own Absolute Dance.

JUDITH SORNBERGER Mansfield, Pa.

No Global Risk Seen in Nuclear Waste in Oceans
An international group of 116 scientists and radiation experts has reported that nuclear wastes dumped into the world's oceans over the decades apparently pose no global danger.
"Any potential problem would be a local one and would pose no threat on a global scale," the scientists said in a written statement issued on Thursday at a conference in Woods Hole, Mass.


Tech Notes; Flashlights With a Twist
FOCUSABLE flashlights, which have lenses that can be twisted to produce broad or narrow beams, are a favorite among airline mechanics, night watchmen and others who need to explore dark spaces.
Some nine million of the flashlights are sold annually, but their sales are held down because of the curse of the black spot -- the shadow that obscures any object in the center of the beam.
Now E. Edmund Ellion appears to have eliminated that problem.

IF you can't get away from New York City this summer, you can round up the family and head for the parks.

A Harvest Of Advice
IT'S usually around this time of year, when the weeds are leaping and the carrots need thinning and the raspberry plants (given to me two springs ago) are still in the same spot where I "heeled them in" and the African lilies probably won't bloom because I didn't bring them out of the cellar until last month and the horseradish roots (they arrived in March) are still in the refrigerator where, the label said, I could store them "for a few days," that I think to myself, I hate gardening.

An Economy Looking for Signals Gets One a Minute
PERHAPS it was naive, but the hope was once in the air that President Clinton would march into Washington, lift the nation's spirits, get employment up and the deficit down and have the economy gliding along like a high-speed train.
That hasn't exactly happened.
Instead Mr.
Clinton has gotten bloodied and bruised as he struggles to push his budget package through a Congress with ideas of its own.
This has dissipated the burst of confidence that greeted the President, and, to Mr.
Clinton's chagrin, the underpowered economy remains on the same unhappy course as when he arrived -- chugging uphill and on the slow track.
Some economic analysts believe that all the inside-the-Beltway mudslinging and mayhem can only cause the economy to lose more steam.
Washington has never been like Moscow of old, with heavy-handed bureaucrats pulling the strings of factories and shops thousands of miles away.
But Washington does send out countless subtle signals every day that influence myriad economic decisions, and in recent weeks those signals have spelled uncertainty with a capital U.
Businesses abhor uncertainty -- it worries them and often paralyzes them.
True, a considerable amount was to be expected, since Mr.
Clinton came into office on the promise of change, committed to cutting the deficit and overhauling health care.
But he seems to have piled it on with a vengeance -- with the help of Congressional Democrats and Republicans, of course.
This uncertainty further clouds an already murky economic picture, with just as many indicators pointing down as up.
Confusion in Washington inarguably hurts the economy to some degree because it has sent corporate executives to the sidelines, anxious for matters to clarify before they get on with the business of expanding, hiring and investing -- paradoxically, the precise economic goals that Mr.
Clinton wants to achieve.
With the investment tax credit here one day and gone the next, with trial balloons being floated about new consumption and payroll taxes, and with the energy tax seemingly changing every few minutes like a kaleidoscope, many corporate executives say they don't know who's on first.
A Tax Free-for-All
And the uncertainty is likely to continue for months to come, through the Administration's anticipated but much delayed effort to reform health care, which accounts for one of every seven dollars spent in the economy.
In its latest turn last week, the White House abandoned an energy tax on the heat content of fuels, and now appears ready to let a Congressional free-for-all determine what energy tax the country should have.
The leader among a raft of unpopular proposals is a transportation tax -- a levy on gasoline, diesel fuel and airline fuel pushed by Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat.
Seeing all this confusion, many executives are asking how they can decide whether to build a new factory or hire new workers when they don't know which new taxes they will face and how large they will be.
"Many businessmen are deferring decisions on hiring and capital spending -- either they don't know what Washington is going to come up with or they don't like what has already been proposed," said Roger Brinner, chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a consulting firm.
"They're uncertain or frozen."
In Mr.
Brinner's view, such uncertainty hardly hurt the first quarter of this year because most investment and hiring decisions had been locked in when Mr.
Clinton took office.
But many analysts agree this uncertainty is hurting the economy now.
In the first quarter, the economy inched upward at a miserably slow nine-tenths of 1 percent.
The Administration is praying for a robust second quarter, and many economists say that just might happen in spite of Washington's budget turmoil.
But if the economic torpor continues, it will hard to push the jobless rate much below 7 percent -- and to fulfill Mr.
Clinton's goal of creating 8 million jobs in four years.
Vicious Cycle
Indeed, if growth doesn't get better and soon, the economy's weakness could metastasize into serious political trouble for Mr.
Clinton, just as it did for George Bush.
That could complicate efforts to push through his economic and health care programs, forming a vicious cycle of uncertainty undercutting the economy and hampering lawmakers, creating more uncertainty, and so on.
Americans, Mr.
Brinner says, will be less game for sacrifice and grand experiments when the economy and their paychecks are going nowhere.
And members of Congress, already in a surly mood, might grow even less loyal to Mr.
Clinton as worries fester that he might not turn around the economy before the 1994 elections.
At the moment, the economy seems to be both accelerating and holding back.
On one hand, businesses seem discouraged by all the confusion in Washington.
But on the other, companies see the economy expanding, although slowly, quarter after quarter, and as orders flow in, they feel obligated to increase hiring.
"Even though companies are worried about new laws or taxes and all the uncertainty, that is very much overridden by the fact that new orders keep coming in," said Mitchell Fromstein, chief executive officer of Manpower Inc., the temporary help company.
For businesses, predicting how the economy will behave in six months is about as difficult as predicting whether Mr.
Clinton will stop stumbling by then.
On the negative side, consumer and business confidence are dipping, retail sales are weak and factories have scaled back their investment plans.
Brighter news, however, comes from the strong pickup in employment in May and surprisingly robust gains in car and housing sales.
What economic strength there is seems concentrated in sectors highly sensitive to interest rates.
Mr.
Clinton can claim some responsibility for that, since long-term interest rates dropped sharply after he was elected and unveiled his $500 billion deficit reduction package.
Since his $19 billion economic stimulus package went down in flames, he is looking to the sharp fall in interest rates as the economy's salvation, saying it will translate into $100 billion in stimulus.
The trouble is, the combination of tax increases and spending cuts in his budget package is bound to have a numbing effect on the economy -- what economists often call "fiscal drag." Companies complain that higher taxes or dropoffs in government contracts cause them to hire fewer people.
And corporate worries have been aggravated by reports that Mr.
Clinton's health-care package may include hefty payroll taxes of 7 to 10 percent of the wage base.
"We are being more than extremely careful about hiring," said Pepe Piedra, chairman of NeoCAD, a software company in Boulder, Colo.
"There could be a double whammy for us between the enormous tax increases in the economic package and the whammy of new taxes to pay for health-care reform."
One company recently finished a study on whether to modernize an existing American factory or replace it by building a new plant in Mexico.
The study concluded that it was a tossup, but, a company executive indicated, if the Administration pushes through a 10 percent payroll tax for health care, the investment will go south of the border.
With the recent shake-up in the White House, Administration officials nevertheless exude confidence that they will get their economic package passed this summer, that confidence in the economy will rebound and that Mr.
Clinton's popularity will likewise.
If only the American people were as confident.

Johnson Just as Bad Second Time Around
The sequel to Jeff Johnson's first horror show of 1993 was just as frightful for the Yankees tonight.
Five days after the pitcher was pummeled in his season debut, he duplicated the abominable start by being routed for five runs again and not lasting beyond the second inning again.
Johnson's 45-pitch fiasco allowed the Brewers to rush to an early cushion, cruise to a 9-1 victory over the Yankees at County Stadium and end their three-game losing streak.
The disastrous outing likely ended Johnson's sixth stint in the majors.
Manager Buck Showalter was hesitant to even give the left-hander his second start and hinted strongly that Johnson would be demoted to the minor leagues Sunday.


Play About Art Fosters Art
ART is begetting art, or so it seems, at the Schoolhouse, a theater space and gallery, where oil paintings by Michael Patterson in an exhibition titled "Conversations/Villages/Open Spaces" is on through July 4.
The show provides a fitting segue to the play, or is it the other way around?
"Sight Unseen" by Donald Margulies is about the purpose of art -- and a lot more -- but how many plays concern themselves with contemporary painters in the first place?


Maria Ritter, Chip Farnham
Maria Ritter and Joseph Farnham love cats, the ocean, flowers that grow by the sea, skinny-dipping, full moons, books and Cajun music, all of which they playfully incorporated into their June 5 wedding.
They met 15 years ago as students at the Gunnery, a boarding school in Washington, Conn.
"We were always getting yelled at for P.D.A. -- public display of affection," the bride recalled.


Lighten Up!
This week, buy a hammock.
Plant all the annual flower seeds you thought it was too late to plant.
I'm tossing in scarlet zinnias, lavatera, cosmos, lemon gem marigolds and spider flowers.
They'll come into their own by late summer.
Then read the accompanying article and take a nap.
Go see "Dave" or something even sillier.
Do not buy a single garden book.
Don't talk to any gardeners.
They might give you a plant.


Is Music Ever Mute On Politics?
When Wilhelm Furtwangler took the witness stand during de-Nazification hearings after World War II, he was challenged to defend his past.
Hadn't he, as music director of the Berlin Philharmonic, been a central figure in the Nazi cultural apparatus?
Didn't he lend his prestige to the murderous regime instead of leaving in protest?
Furtwangler testified: "It was my intention -- and this is the reason I did not leave Germany -- to prove that art means more than politics."
He was more than a bit naive.
In a recent Furtwangler biography, "The Devil's Music Master," Sam H. Shirakawa argues that the conductor consistently fought the regime from within, even aiding Jewish musicians; Furtwangler believed that great music could remain unsullied by Nazi pressures.
But it is clear that art cannot be completely separated from politics.
Art can be a tool of politics; it can use politics.
Some even assert that art is simply politics by other means.
It is certainly not a world apart.


No Excuses, No Solace As Big Names Stumble
Curtis Strange, Paul Azinger and Seve Ballesteros head into next week's United States Open under less than ideal circumstances after their showing at this week's Buick Classic.
These three, along with several other prominent players on the PGA Tour like John Daly, performed miserably in this week's tournament at the Westchester Country Club and missed the cut.


White-Hispanic Ticket Grabs At a Black Mayor's Coalition
FOUR years ago, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the racket-busting prosecutor who spent the 80's as the scourge of Wall Street and the mob, nearly kept David N. Dinkins from becoming the first black mayor of New York -- simply because he was white.
In a town where Democrats outnumber Republicans by 5 to 1, hordes of white voters deserted their party and Mr.
Dinkins, an heir of the Tammany Democratic machine.
Mr.
Dinkins won by just two percentage points after cobbling together a fragile coalition of blacks, liberal whites and Hispanic voters in an appeal for tolerance and racial healing.


Bernstein: Yet More Surprises?
If anyone still doubts Leonard Bernstein's status as an American folk hero, the matter should be put to rest this summer.
Bernstein's 75th birthday, on Aug. 25, will be celebrated worldwide, beginning on Monday with the New York Philharmonic's weeklong tribute to its former music director.
Sony Classical is scheduled to complete its massive 119-CD "Royal Collection" of Bernstein recordings by the end of the year, and Deutsche Grammophon's release of his final recordings is now complete.
With all the Bernstein videos flooding the market, it is only a matter of time before someone in Nashville, where Bernstein's archives now reside, "sights" him leaping passionately into the air at the climax of Mahler's "Resurrection" Symphony.
Passion is what Bernstein's music-making was all about.
In his concerts, recordings, teaching, writing, speaking, one always sensed a life-or-death need to communicate the composer's message.
Always controversial, he was damned in many quarters for exhibitionism on the podium, for exaggerating the music's emotional content at the expense of its structural integrity, for vulgarizing a dignified art form.
In his early days and well into his Philharmonic tenure, critics labeled his interpretations brash and immature.
Yet his audiences grew inexorably.
Today, listeners to his recordings from that era join Stravinsky in saying "Wow!"


MAYOR AND COUNCIL MAKE BUDGET PACT FOR NEW YORK CITY
Mayor David N. Dinkins and the New York City Council agreed early yesterday morning on a $31.2 billion budget that holds taxes steady, clips some social programs but still grows by nearly $1.8 billion over last year's adopted budget.
The Council's leaders and the administration reached an accord at 4:30 yesterday morning, resolving a week of tense and at times acrimonious negotiations over the shape of nearly $300 million in spending cuts by agreeing not to cut services quite so deeply as the Mayor had initially proposed.

Waterfalls Offer Relief for the Body, Renewal for the Soul
Ever since Moses struck the rock, and it gushed forth, bringing cooling water to the blistered desert landscape, the waterfall has stood for all things good.
It stands for creativity, abundance and life, for relief from drought and the burning of the sun, for the cessation of thirst, both physical and spiritual.
The Makers of the Tarzan movies instictively understood the waterfall's powerful message.
Every Tarzan movie builds toward the eye-popping moment when the arrogant white hunter, at the head of a long line of native bearers, breaks through the sweltering jungle and, deafened by the roar, beholds stock film of Victoria Falls.
This is the moment when the audience realizes that there are some things even bigger than bwana's greed and ambition.
It is the moment when nature reclaims its due and humbles the puny fellow in the ridiculous pith helmet.

Focus: Beaufort, S.C.; Putting an Old Saw to Work in the South
HERE in this riverside city of 10,000, where gracious mansions were seized early in the Civil War by Union forces, a new invader has stormed the town.
As before, the draw is real estate.
With its picturesque harbor, quaint downtown and elegant homes, Beaufort (pronounced BYEW-furt) has become a favored location for moviemakers.
While one production company was filming in a rural area outside town at the end of May, Paramount was scouring the city with a real estate broker, looking for just the right house.

A number of right-to-die advocates here have created what is apparently the nation's first organization intended to provide professionals who will help terminally ill people kill themselves.

Turnback the Alarm Gets Well Soon
Turnback the Alarm, who missed 10 months of racing after a severe injury last summer, continued to make long strides in her remarkable comeback yesterday when she won the $150,000 Hempstead Handicap at Belmont Park and anointed herself as one of the premiere fillies in the sport.
The 4-year-old gray, who is rapidly becoming a medical as well as a racing marvel, won her second Grade I stakes in three weeks as she outran a strong field of five rivals and, with a relentless move in the homestretch, beat Deputation to the wire by a length and a half.
And in the duel for second place, Deputation edged You'd Be Surprised by a nose while nobody else came within 14 lengths of the leaders.

What Do Clothes Mean To an Artist Anyway?
"FALL FROM FASHION" at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is not about fashion, at least not in the haute couture or Seventh Avenue sense of the term.
It is rather a comment on clothing and its significance, as perceived by artists.
The show, which was organized by the museum's director, Barry A. Rosenberg, comes with a glossy catalogue.
Unfortunately, too many of its pages are virtually empty and, as if to compensate, the layout is dreadfully tricky.
What is more, the silver cover aims to be provocative by featuring a photograph of a bearded, ponytailed young man in a dowdy dress, along with the question "Are Today's Artists Hung Up on Clothing?"


Device Makes Drunken Drivers Nonstarters
To the Editor:
A Manhattan bicyclist was dragged eight blocks after having been hit by a drunken driver, whose license had been repeatedly suspended and who was forbidden to drive (news article, June 1).
A technological development promises to reduce the problem of drunken driving by those who have lost their licenses: the ignition interlock device.
Attached to a car's ignition, this miniaturized "breathalyzer" prevents the car from being started if the driver "blows" too high an alcohol reading.
Circumvention seems less a problem than was feared, and there is reason to believe that the basic drinking habits of drivers may be altered.

To the Editor:
Irwin Landau ("Why a Pound of Coffee Weighs 13 Oz.," Viewpoints, May 23) may already be a little behind the times when it comes to Maxwell House coffee.
Maxwell House Colombian is down to 12 ounces a can and its Master Blend tips the scales at 11.5 ounces.
All cans have exactly the same dimensions as the company's 16-ounce "1812" brand.
PHILIP KESSLER Westport, Conn., May 25

Conversations/Natasha Dudinska; From Prague, a Student Of Lost Ideals and New-Found Evils
COMING of age politically has come too fast for Natasha Dudinska, a displaced idealist from a land once called Czechoslovakia.
In four years, she has passed from student to revolutionary to political organizer and back to student again, as her country has passed from Communism to liberation to dividing against itself.
Once, she was studying to be a diplomat.
Now she disdains power.
It's true, she says, that power corrupts.
In 1989, Ms.
Dudinska (her name is pronounced NAH-tah-shah DOO-din-shkah) suddenly was thrust to prominence as a leader of the college students whose protests sealed the doom of the Communist regime and helped restore self-determination to Czechoslovakia.
She was featured in documentaries about courage.
Then she watched helplessly as political leaders, without a referendum, determined that her nation would split into Czech and Slovak republics.
Now, she and friends are completing a documentary about what to her is another misuse of Europe's nationalisms, the slaughter in the Balkans.

The Summer Ritual: Music Out-of-Doors
THE collaboration of musicians and the out-of-doors in Beethoven's Ninth or Bach's Brandenburgs, or even Schubert's "Trout" Quintet, can be quite glorious even when it encompasses the occasional cricket solo or thunderclap percussion.
Sometimes it even includes a seascape as backdrop or intoxicating gardens in full bloom.
And if one is truly fortunate, nature's own Klieg light, the moon, illuminates a masterpiece.
And always there is the barely audible rustle of sheet music.
Over the next few weeks a pleasant cacophany of creatures and natural phenomena will join with classical musicians in the perennial union.
And Connecticut, with its Berkshire foothills to the north and seascapes to the south, offers a variety of settings for the quintessential summer ritual.
One can board a 19th-century steamship in Mystic and revel in authentically performed Renaissance music while cruising the Sound.
Or, on a mountaintop in Falls Village just above the Appalachian Trail, a music lover can absorb string quartet music in a shed built to resonate like the interior of a violin.
Festival venues range from the intimate to the grandiose.
And while most of the settings encourage spreading a picnic on a grassy knoll or cracking a croquet ball while a brass quintet plays some buoyant preconcert selections, at the moment of truth -- the concert itself -- the music making is anything but casual.

Two Shows With Links to the Past
WESTCHESTER has returned to the past with two shows, one of tintypes at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, the other of Impressionistic paintings at the Hammond Museum in North Salem.
In the beginning was the daguerreotype, a silvered copper plate in which the reflections of faces, figures and landscape were fixed forever.
There was also the calotype, an image made with paper negative and positive.
Then came the ambrotype, which is a kind of daguerreotype except that it involves a negative coated with collodion, which becomes a positive when laid on a dark ground.
A cheap, virtually mass-produced variant of this was the tintype, an image on a thin sheet of iron, which, when painted, has the look of folk art.


About That American Industrial Policy . . .
To the Editor:
Regarding "Wall Street: The Reason It's So Far From Washington" (Viewpoints, May 9) and "An Industrial Policy Is Not Outdated" (Letters, May 30), one often-heard phrase is that the Government cannot pick "winners and losers."
People seem to forget that our foreign competitors have been doing just that -- the Japanese, for example, in optoelectronics and the Europeans, through the Airbus joint venture, in the large long-distance commercial aircraft business.


Spielberg Grapples With the Horror Of the Holocaust
At a railway siding, a Nazi commandant and his servile lieutenants feast on fruit and drink punch from a crystal bowl while hundreds of terrified Jews -- penned in stifling cattle cars -- beseech their captors for water.
Sixty miles from Auschwitz, near the site where this horror unfolded a half century ago, Steven Spielberg was directing this scene from "Schindler's List." Based on the acclaimed 1982 book by Thomas Keneally, the film tells the story of a vain German businessman, Oskar Schindler, who saved the lives of his 1,300 Jewish factory workers at the height of the Holocaust.

At 50, Conner Wary of Whitbread
The usually confident and often cocky Dennis Conner turns hesitant when it comes to a discussion about sailing in the Whitbread Round the World Race.
This attitudinal quirk has nothing to do with his team's ability to win, but rather, whether Conner wants to sail with his team.
"I have some trepidation about it, honestly," the 50-year-old Conner said in an interview last week.
"This is a young man's deal. When you get down to the Roaring Forties, you're cold and wet, and there are no showers. There is no way to get away."

If any two drivers spanned the spectrum of motor racing in May at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, those two were Emerson Fittipaldi and Bobby Rahal.
Fittipaldi used an alert late-race restart to win his second Indianapolis 500, while Rahal was bumped from the lineup with a few minutes left in qualifying and missed his first Indy 500 since he started coming there in 1982.


Mysterious Movement at Andrea Electronics
ADVOCATES of the theory of efficient markets may have a hard time explaining the trading in Andrea Electronics, whose shares have repeatedly moved 50 percent or more in a day, without any new information.
The bullish story on Andrea is that it has a wondrous device that will suppress street noise on pay telephones.
It hasn't sold any systems yet, and the GTE Corporation, for one, says it is happy with alternative systems and has not talked to Andrea.
But Bellcore, the research arm of the regional Bell companies, is looking at the system.

Unconventional College Finds Adults Are Good Students
AT Charter Oak State College in Connecticut there are no classrooms and no curriculum.
It does have a faculty but its members don't teach.
Ten percent of its students -- average age close to 40 -- live outside the state.
Some even live outside the country.
The college has no campus, but exists in a suite of rooms in a commercial office and shopping complex.
It is a most unusual place.
It is also relatively unknown.
Ask most people about Charter Oak and they might talk about the tree revered in early Connecticut history, where the colony's charter was hidden.
But a college?


Your Home: Mitchell-Lama; Desirable And Now, Available
AMONG the most desirable housing built in New York City for moderate-income families between in the 1960's and early 1970's were its 151,000 Mitchell-Lama apartments.
Some had spectacular views over the Hudson or East River, others were at the oceanfront or within walking distance of Lincoln Center or Greenwich Village.
Constructed with heavy subsidies from municipal and state sources and blessed with tax breaks, they provided thousands of families with an attractive apartment at a relatively low and stable cost, either as a rental or a co-op with a nominal share price.


Unshackled, Unconventional Sculptor
"I THINK I did well following my nose," said the sculptor John Chamberlain.
With little formal training and a resolute refusal to play by the rules the second-generation New York School artist innovated a bold development in postwar art.
Thirty-six years ago Mr.
Chamberlain ripped two fenders off a 1929 Ford at the home of Larry Rivers in Southampton and welded them into an abstract sculpture called "Shortstop." In so doing, he invented a method and medium for which he is well known.
His work is in the collections of institutions like the Museum of Modern Art and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.
Exhibitions attract fans from the Parrish to Paris.
Mr.
Chamberlain is in a position to savor success, but he continues to sniff out new challenges.


Ways to Make the Most of the Strawberry Season
THE local strawberry crop is late this year, as it was last year, making the lush, ripe berries more welcome than ever.
The season is now in full swing.
Farm stands and markets throughout the region are overflowing with berries by the quart.
Pickers take to the fields, and even some supermarkets have caught on and are selling locally grown strawberries from fields that perfume the air.


Waiting for a Rudder at I.N.S.
When the freighter Golden Venture ran aground off Queens last weekend, it sparked the latest crisis to confront an immigration agency that has lurched from controversy to controversy without a leader since President Clinton took office.
At a most sensitive time in immigration history, Mr.
Clinton has not yet nominated an Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner or publicly articulated an immigration policy distinct from his Republican predecessor.
As most senior immigration jobs are empty, the agency is being run by holdovers from the Bush Administration in Washington.
And into the vacuum local I.N.S. directors, career officials like William S. Slattery in New York, have moved to reassert their power and law-enforcement priorities.

Where the Clothes Match the Music
IN SoHo's deepest heartland, on Spring Street near West Broadway, 100 percent polyester double-knit shirts are being snapped up by 23-year-olds for $74 apiece.
"They're very 'Mambo Kings,' very retro," said Joseph Melendez, the manager of Union, the 300-square-foot shop that throbbed with hip-hop music on a recent Friday afternoon.
Union also carries regulation blue nylon mail-carrier jackets with U.S.
Mail patches ($110) and shapeless brown shirts with the yellow logo of the United Parcel Service ($42): "American work wear, utility kind of stuff," said James Jebbia, an owner.

Bullying Is Not Leading
To the Editor:
James Oestreich states that "as in every other area of music, the balance between control and freedom is intricate and delicate." This observation has direct bearing on the discussion in the article "Playing (and Singing) Politics" in the same issue.
Composers who use art as a bully pulpit, insisting on a narrow interpretation, ignore that delicate balance between freedom and control.
By its very nature, music is an art of multiple meanings.
And in music, as in most areas of life, we learn best by example.
By this I mean that we are moved by lessons of the heart, communicated with a generosity of spirit.
Thus, we are led rather than subdued.
MARY L. SENN Rome, N. Y.


THEATER
June
"CAMELOT." Playing the dashing Sir Lancelot du Lac, who lures Queen Guenevere away from King Arthur, Robert Goulet found overnight stardom on Broadway in the original production of Lerner and Loewe's musical.
That was in 1960.
Now he's back in a touring production of the show about the Knights of the Round Table and their ladies fair.
Only this time he's appearing as King Arthur.
Among other things, that means he'll be singing "I Wonder What the King Is Doing Tonight" instead of "If Ever I Would Leave You." Steve Blanchard and Patricia Kies are featured as Lancelot and Guenevere.
Previews begin Thursday; opens June 21.
Gershwin Theater, 221 West 51st, Manhattan.
Performances: Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 P.M.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 P.M.
No Sunday performances.
Tickets: $45 to $65.
Information: (212) 307-4100.
"A PERFECT GANESH." Two women, portrayed by Frances Sternhagen and Zoe Caldwell, take a trip to India in the newest play by Terrence McNally.
Fisher Stevens turns up as the various men -- some 20 of them -- they encounter along the way.
Ganesh, it seems, is the Hindu god of good fortune, who also puts in an appearance.
The director is John Tillinger, who has staged such successful McNally dramas as "Lips Together, Teeth Apart" and "The Lisbon Traviata." Currently in previews; opens June 27.
Manhattan Theater Club at City Center, Stage I, 131 West 55th Street, Manhattan.
Performances (through Aug. 22.): Tuesdays through Fridays at 8 P.M.; Saturdays, 2:30 and 8 P.M.; Sundays, 2:30 and 7 P.M.
Tickets: $35.
Information: (212) 581-1212.

"IN THE SUMMER HOUSE." Jane Bowles's 1953 drama about a group of maladjusted Southern Californians and their efforts to evade reality was once described by Tennessee Williams as "the most original play I have ever read." This will be the first directorial undertaking of Joanne Akalaitis since she was abruptly deposed last spring as the artistic director of the Joseph Papp Public Theater.
Philip Glass is composing new music for the play, and George Tsypin is designing the scenery.
Previews begin July 8; opens Aug. 1.

You've got to hand it to the director and lyricist Martin Charnin, the composer Charles Strouse and the book writer Thomas Meehan: they don't give up.

"BLACK COMEDY" and "THE WHITE LIARS." Nancy Marchand is to star in this revival of two one-act plays by Peter Shaffer, first presented on Broadway in 1967.
The latter piece, the curtain-raiser, involves a young man and a fraudulent fortuneteller.
The former is about a sculptor, hoping to exhibit his wares to a wealthy buyer, until the lights in his apartment go out.
Mr.
Shaffer's trick is to reverse light and dark.
When the electricity is on, the stage is dark.
When it goes off, the stage lights come up, allowing the audience to observe a variety of characters stumbling over one another and the furniture.
Gerald Gutierrez directs.
Previews begin Aug. 10; opens Aug. 26; closes Oct. 10.

Playing It Close To the Head
The small round head appears to be the signature look of this summer; it's achieved with a skull cap crocheted or knitted from linen or cotton yarn in patterns that are airy and open.
There is even an evening version in sparkling Lurex (above left) that young people are wearing to evening parties.
The skull cap that is sweeping the Western fashion scene is an adaptation of African and Oriental regional head coverings.
The styles that cover more of the head than the originals often resemble bathing caps with the same fit that flattens the hair and drastically changes the silhouette of the head.

Mayor's Son Gets a Scholarship, and Protest Arises
A century-old system of political patronage here has been sidetracked by public anger over Mayor Sidney Barthelemy's awarding of a Tulane University scholarship to his own son.
On Friday, Mayor Barthelemy tried to defuse the anger by announcing that his son, Sidney 2d, would not, after all, attend Tulane.
And the private college in turn announced it would not honor mayoral and legislative scholarships until the rules for the patronage awards are changed.

To Arms! To Arms! White Fly is Here
THE goal now is to keep the garden blooming through the sunny months.
If all goes well, everything should be nearly weedless and trouble free.
This does require a few extra hours outdoors, but all too often uninvited troubles appear.
One of the most discouraging is white fly.
These tiny insect pests seem to appear out of nowhere, and almost every kind of soft succulent leaf is to their liking.
They keep away from a few annuals like impatiens and begonias, but vegetable gardeners know this nuisance well, especially on squash and tomato plants.

Gone Fishin': A Father, a Daughter, a Dingy and a Pair of Fluke
The tides that sweep through Jones Beach Inlet carry with them a spectacular array of wildlife, each in its season.
In summer, there are ducks and geese, stripers and blues, egrets and herons.
In fall these warm weather residents head south and the patient observer will sometimes glimpse dolphins and whales.
In winter, Canada geese and harbor seals frequent the marshy islands of Long Island's Great South Bay and Hempstead Bay, yielding in spring to blackfish, flounder and fluke.
Mike McLaughlin is second-in-command at Ed's Fishing station, a white clapboard snack bar/boat livery/ tackle shop in Point Lookout, L.I., on the western shore of Jones Beach Inlet.
Mack was born in the Bronx, summered in Point Lookout, served in Danang during the Tet offensive, left the Army but stayed in Vietnam with Chase Manhattan, took a Vietnamese bride, and on his return, knocked around the Northeast until the tides finally beached him at Ed's.

Step by Step, the State Moves Toward Integration
THE new state legislation requiring all towns and cities to join regional discussions on achieving greater racial diversity in their public schools leaves much unstated because of the volatile politics of race.

As a result, officials of organizations receiving money from United Way, an umbrella group that collects money for various charities, say they may now have to cut staff and possibly programs and turn to other fund-raising efforts to meet their budgets.

Out and Organized
IN big, loopy letters, Mary Hansen wrote the word "homosexual" on the blackboard, then turned to face the 25 unruly students in Anne Corey's ninth-grade humanities class at the High School of Telecommunications Arts and Technology in Brooklyn.
"Who's the babe?" one boy asked.
A few others hooted.
Ms.
Hansen, unfazed, asked them to divide into groups and make lists of words that came to mind when they thought about the one she had just finished writing.
"And don't censor yourself," she said.
"Seriously, we can handle it."
This was Ms.
Hansen's ninth such "peer training" session -- designed to promote tolerance of homosexuals among straight teen-agers and to provide role models for gay ones.
Her supervisor, David Nieves, who accompanied her, had led more than 100 peer trainings at other high schools and colleges.
There wasn't much they had not seen before: students unwilling to touch the paper on which the words were written; others reduced to shrieks when the lists were read aloud.
Ms.
Hansen just smiled and copied their replies onto the board.


Federal Inquiry Into Death of Artist in Street Fight
Federal civil-rights prosecutors in Manhattan and Washington are looking into the death of Grady Alexis, an artist killed two years ago in a Greenwich Village street fight involving an off-duty police officer.
James L. Cott, chief of the civil rights unit in the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan, confirmed on Friday that the incident that led to Mr.
Alexis's death was under review by his office and the Civil Rights Division of the Justice Department.
He declined to discuss details of the case, but he said that such a review can be -- but is not necessarily -- a precursor to the filing of Federal civil-rights charges.

About That American Industrial Policy . . .
To the Editor:
Prof.
William F. Schreiber of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (Letters, May 30) justifies a national industrial policy on the grounds that it was our wonderfully efficient Government that made possible the development of computers, aircraft and pharmaceuticals, and that even farming wouldn't be so productive if it weren't for agricultural supports.
Collectivists speak with such assurance because they play the game with a stacked deck.
Government can stick its nose, uninvited, into any industry -- and then claim credit for every achievement of that industry ever after.
A private company has no choice but to put up with Government interference -- filling out forms, appearing before commissions and paying large taxes.

An Exuberant Epson: No Simple Deals
IF you play a large number of bridge deals, what percentage would you expect to consist of slam contracts?
Game contracts?
Part-score contracts?
Based on an analysis of 224 deals in the 1957 world championship, the answer is 10-48-42.
This indicates that in a normal session of play one can expect two or three slams, with games slightly outnumbering part scores for the rest of the deals.
If a session is particularly exciting, the slam percentage will go up and the part-score percentage down.
In this respect the deals in the first session of the Epson Worldwide Bridge Contest eight days ago were off the scale: 26-70-4.
The second session was also skewed, but less so: 10-75-15. (Only the first 24 deals, played by all contestants, are taken into account, and 5 deals likely to end in doubled part-score contracts have been ignored.)


On Capitol Hill, a Top Aide With No Belief in Age Limits
Even the baby-boomer White House, awash with aides under 30 years old, has few who can rival Henry Ellenbogen, the Boy Wonder of Capitol Hill.
At age 20, he hasn't yet completed his senior year as a history and science major at Harvard University, but as administrative assistant to a Florida Congressman, he manages a $1 million budget, supervises a staff of 17 and holds a job that usually requires at least 10 years experience in Congressional affairs.


If Business Is Better, What About 3M?
IF a weak economy is bad for a stock, why is it good for the stock market?
That puzzler reasserted itself when the stock market turned around and began to rise late last week, on the heels of a surprising announcement from one of the economy's most trusted bellwethers, the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company.


Should We Revive the Dinosaurs?
Much as we hate to be drawn into the frenzied hype for Steven Spielberg's "Jurassic Park," it is hard to ignore a megabuck movie that has already become grist for museum displays, op-ed commentary, "Nightline" and lively debate among scientists.
The film's central notion -- that arrogant, unscrupulous or unthinking scientists might bring long-extinct dinosaurs back to life -- has clearly struck a chord.
The faint of heart may rest assured that even the maddest of scientists will not have the capability any time soon of resurrecting the dinosaurs.
The movie, like Michael Crichton's book on which it was based, hypothesizes that blood-sucking mosquitoes dined on the dinos, and immediately afterward got stuck in tree resin that later hardened to amber, preserving the mosquitoes and the dinosaur blood for tens of millions of years.
Modern scientists are then able, in the movie, to extract the blood from the amber, isolate a fragment of dinosaur DNA, stick it into an egg, and presto -- out comes a new dinosaur.


Police Who Cut Through Red Tape
THE children who were waiting idly for the morning school bus in their apartment complex's parking lot eagerly ran over to the two adults who pulled into a parking space near the building's side entrance.
The children exchanged high fives and greetings with the two men, who asked them about homework, problems with siblings and classmates and their after-school plans.
Such a display of enthusiasm was a cheerful sight on a late May morning, yet hardly surprising for what seemed to be a friendly exchange between neighbors.


Eateries Where the Slupring Is Easy
SCENES from "Tampopo," Juzo Itami's 1987 Japanese noodle western, are now being played out in restaurants all over Manhattan.
Loud slurping sounds can be heard as customers in Japanese noodle shops do justice to huge platters, bowls and sometimes caldrons filled with skeins of velvety udon, soba, larmen and ramen garnished with fish, meat, chicken, tofu, seaweed, vegetables and such.
When it comes to noodles, the mannerly, ceremonious Japanese let loose: slurping is a show of satisfaction reserved for this category of foods, which, like the sound effects themselves, evolved from peasant-class customs over hundreds of years.
In Tokyo alone, there are tens of thousands of noodle shops, specializing in soba, or buckwheat noodles, with the best handmade on the premises daily.
New York has a small number of Japanese noodle restaurants, but they join the craze for pasta led by the Italians and reinforced by Chinese noodle shops all over town.


Pandering To Male Fantasies
To the Editor:
Let's face it: What every man wants (though few would admit it) is a woman capable of fulfilling his every sexual desire who will then make him a nice dinner and tuck him into bed.
Since most wives and girlfriends are incapable of playing this role, or unwilling to, a man will pay to see his ideal woman flickering across the screen.
Male movie executives know this and work it for all it's worth.

French Movies Offer Tickets To Controversy
Nowhere in the world are films still taken as seriously as they are in Paris.
Old films, new films, dreadful films and sublime films.
In any week, nearly 300 different movies are available in theaters that vary in size and decor from the big and the grand to the minuscule and the barely functional.
On one recent Saturday afternoon I watched the first-run "Petain" in a 28-seat theater at the complex called the 7 Parnassiens.
There were five other people in the house. (Showing at adjoining theaters in the same complex: "Indecent Proposal," "The Crying Game," "Singles," "Toys" and "Enchanted April.") Moviegoing of such intimacy becomes something akin to group therapy.
Only in Paris, too, could there be the kind of controversy that now surrounds "Francois Truffaut: Portraits Voles" ("Francois Truffaut: Stolen Portraits"), a fascinating, very good (if incomplete) new feature-length documentary about the life and work of the artist who, when he was alive, was often dismissed as being too bourgeois.
The man whom his detractors thought to be too nice, too gentle, too eager to please, is now revealed to have been a rat.

Editorial Notebook; Ways and Means
With jurisdiction over taxes, trade law, health and welfare, the House Ways and Means Committee wields tremendous power.
The chairman's job is tough and time-consuming.
But for Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, the position is not without its rewards.
A story in Congressional Quarterly reveals Mr.
Rostenkowski as a master -- perhaps the master -- of the Congressional art of princely living.
The account, written by Phil Kuntz, spotlights two scandals that are central to the current battle over political reform: the use of campaign war chests as personal slush funds, and the lobbyist-provided perks that guarantee Mr.
Rostenkowski and many of his colleagues a life of blissful bondage.


Uffizi Gallery Reopening Set For Next Week
After the car bomb explosion that blasted through the Uffizi Gallery in Florence on May 27, the city authorities are now hoping to reopen part of it on June 20.
On that day visitors will be able to enter the east wing of the gallery -- relatively undamaged in the explosion -- that is home to the museum's unrivaled collection of Botticellis and other Italian works from the 13th-century Giotto to 16th-century artists.


MISSILE IS TESTED BY NORTH KOREANS
While North Korea's negotiators were dragging out the standoff over a nuclear non-proliferation treaty that ended on Friday at the United Nations, the Communist Government's engineers conducted what appears to be the first successful test of the country's homegrown mid-range missile, one that Japanese officials fear could travel as far as some of Japan's most populous cities.
The tests, conducted on the Sea of Japan on May 29 and 30, are believed to have involved the Rodong 1, a missile North Korea has been developing for several years and is preparing to export to Iran in return for oil.
American intelligence officials have said that the missile is believed to be capable of carrying a payload of chemical weapons, or perhaps a small nuclear device.


New Strength for U.N. Peacekeepers: U.S. Might
In staging air and ground strikes against the militia of a Somali faction leader, United Nations forces have expanded the United Nations mandate in peacekeeping operations, while raising the issue of whether efforts by the world organization must always depend on United States firepower.
From Bosnia to Cambodia, United Nations peacekeepers fire when they are fired upon.
But they do not conduct major punitive raids to neutralize stubborn foes.


Street Crackdown's Aim: Turn Down That Stereo!
Car alarms, barking dogs, garbage trucks, jackhammers.

But this weekend, residents of at least one neighborhood may be finding it a little easier to get some rest.
On Friday night, the police cracked down on one of the most irritating sources of noise, confiscating 19 cars with stereo "boom boxes" from the noisy streets of Washington Heights.

Albany Pressured to Draw Plans to Reduce Pollution
Imagine the impact on New York City traffic if large stretches of the Gowanus Expressway, the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway, and the Queensboro and Williamsburg Bridges had to be shut down because there was no longer money for repairs.
That's the nightmare that state officials are depicting to prod the Legislature into enacting a plan that would meet the requirements of the Federal Clean Air Act before the current legislative session is scheduled to end June 25.
Failure to do so could cost the state billions in roadway repair dollars.

Natalie Cole Steps Out Of Her Father's Shadow
Natalie Cole's new album, "Take a Look," should erase any lingering doubts that the 1991 blockbuster "Unforgettable With Love" was an inspired, one-of-kind stroke of pop nostalgia.
Recorded with many of the same arrangers and players, the new album also focuses on jazz and pre-rock pop songs, many of them standards lavishly arranged for orchestra.
But if the sound of "Take a Look" (Elektra 9 61496; CD and cassette) is similar to that of "Unforgettable," a tribute to her father, Nat (King) Cole, its perspective is broader and quirkier.
And it firmly establishes Ms.
Cole as a polished pop-jazz stylist of conservative temperament who is a hybrid of her father, Ella Fitzgerald and the young Aretha Franklin.


Why Minorities Need Special Help
Recently the media has highlighted the position of some people that racially and ethnically defined programs deprive them of benefits.
The article on the Legal Education Access Program at Touro College  [ "L.I. Law Schools Aim for 'Diversity' With New Intensity," May 16 ]  included a comment by a white male that the program "gives an academic advantage to minorities." We are struggling with our complex reactions to this contention.
We are fully aware that many whites were victimized by prejudice in the past.
For example, earlier in this century Irish-American immigrants were confronted with signs posted by employers declaring, "Irish and Dos Need Not Apply." Further, people of all races are discriminated against on the basis of class, sexual preference, physical ability, weight and many other physical and psychological characteristics, most of which are beyond their control.
These and all forms of oppression are atrocities which must be abolished.

THERE are 250 million Americans and every one is convinced he can run his own business, typically a restaurant.

At Work; Poor Women, Rich Dreams
WHEN Donna Nicolardi, a former public school teacher, applied for a Small Business Administration loan to start a business, she was asked for a five-year projection.
"They wanted to see a business plan, but I did not know how to do one," Ms.
Nicolardi said.
"When I contacted companies to do the plan, they wanted more money than I had."
But now, thanks to a 14-month course for unemployed and low-income women, Ms.
Nicolardi, 40, will get her chance.
She hopes to master the basics of business ownership and make a go of her company, A+ Kidlings Inc., which specializes in educational books and games and toys that "help children learn moral lessons and self-esteem."


The Creative Ferment Behind the Glass Boxes
Has the hour arrived for a manifesto?
Is it time for a book to rouse architects from their recessionary torpor and chart a new course for their art?
Twenty-seven years have passed since Robert Venturi's "Complexity and Contradiction in Architecture" outlined a program for post-modernism.
Meanwhile, a new generation of architects, born after World War II, has edged onto the stage.
Where is the document that declares what they stand for?
"Architecture Culture: 1943-1968" will have to do until the real thing comes along.
The book, just published, is hardly a rabble-rousing tract.
As its starchy title makes plain, this is a scholarly work: a "documentary anthology" of writings by architects and critics, selected and annotated with great intelligence and care by Joan Ockman, 40, a professor at Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture, Preservation and Planning, co-publishers of the book with Rizzoli.
Still, the book carries a sly but potent ideological charge.
Robert Venturi called his book a "gentle manifesto." Ms.
Ockman has produced a crypto-manifesto: a smart, gutsy polemic in prim academic wrappers.


Demonstrations By the Masters
MORE than 100 years after Longfellow wrote his poem celebrating the village blacksmith, no fewer than 11 blacksmiths will bend and twist red-hot iron this summer at the Peters Valley Craft Center.
They will show their students how to form Colonial-style hardware and candelabra in the early 19th-century forge.
In other studios, potters, fiber artists, woodworkers and jewelry makers will demonstrate traditional and innovative methods for creating contemporary crafts.
Peters Valley is offering 70 workshops this summer.

Now, more than two years after the Air Force opened its Desktop IV competition with a vow that the contract would be a model for streamlined high-technology procurement, the first batch of computers is almost ready for delivery.

Effort to Bar Plea Deals Is Under Fire

Now, after nearly seven months, the granite walls of the Bronx County Courthouse have not tumbled down as many had feared.

BUSINESS DIARY
THE ECONOMY On Those Worries About Renewed Inflation: Never Mind The Administration must have been greatly relieved at Friday's report on inflation -- or, at least in May, the lack of it.
Before the report, the White House kept saying how important low interest rates were in keeping the economy on the mend.
And it kept up the pressure on the Federal Reserve not to raise rates, fearing that if prices jumped again, the central bank might act quickly.
Then it turned out that producer prices were unchanged last month -- erasing, in many economists' minds, the specter of an inflationary surge.
Suddenly, the White House anxiety vanished, with President Clinton's chief economic adviser, Laura D'Andrea Tyson, even saying that she hadn't really been worried by the earlier increases in producer prices -- 0.6 percent in April, 0.4 percent in March.
Financial markets had obviously been worried, though, because interest rates fell sharply in heavy buying in the bond market.
A Crumbling Budget Plan Imagine a sizable block of stone.
Then imagine a horde of would-be sculptors attacking it with chisels and hammers.
And when, their passion spent, they pull back to pronounce their work complete, nothing is left but a pebble.
That seems the likely fate of President Clinton's ambitious economic plan.
Yes, something may still pass Congress, but how much of the original vision will remain?
The latest, and biggest, hunk of stone to crash to the floor was the proposed tax on the heat content of fuels, which Mr.
Clinton abandoned last week in the face of rising opposition.
This was to raise nearly a third of the $250 billion in sought-for new taxes, and any compromise that now emerges -- like a gasoline tax -- is sure to fall short.
When the pebble is finally thrown at the deficit, that monster probably won't even flinch.
Fly Now -- or Sue Later You dash to the gate, ticket in hand, but the plane is full.
To most people, this is cause for rejoicing, because the airline will hand you several hundred dollars to ease the pain -- and also probably get you on a plane in a couple of hours.
Most people would gladly sit and read for $100 or so an hour.
But there are, inevitably, some I'm-not-going-to-take-it types, and a Federal appeals court has ruled that if they're bumped, they can sue for damages.
But airlines are not about to alter their meticulously calibrated overbooking formulas -- only one traveler in 10,000 is grounded under protest.
And since punitive damages are not allowed, that one is unlikely to take on a legal crusade.
Boesky, Back From the Gutter The rich are indeed different.
They may say they're broke, but that's not quite what they mean.
After Ivan Boesky settled insider-trading charges, paying a $100 million fine, he gladly opened his wallet to show the bare, lonely leather.
Of course his wife, Seema, had a little left -- $100 million or so -- and Mr.
Boesky quickly demanded half.
Last week, as part of a divorce settlement, he got a bit less than that, but he did get $20 million, a $2.5 million house and -- so that he wouldn't have to dip into capital -- $180,000 a year in pocket money.
Less Deadly Lighters Each year, Americans buy half a billion butane lighters -- that's two for every woman, man and child.
It's that child that's the problem.
Children, being children, tend to play with lighters -- causing, each year, an estimated 5,000 fires, and 150 deaths.
So last week the Consumer Product Safety Commission ordered manufacturers to make lighters too difficult for most children under 5 to operate.
Now there's an idea: just make them too difficult for most adults to operate, too, and a few people might wind up giving their lungs a break. 'Diet Plate'?
Prove It!
What, exactly, does "diet plate" mean on a restaurant menu?
Right now, just about anything.
If your local diner wants to write "diet plate" next to a listing for steak, french fries and buttered roll, it's free to do so.
Or it can use a cute little heart symbol, suggesting that this meal can somehow substitute for a morning jog.
And it doesn't take much to convince customers, who are all too happy to believe that the good stuff is also the healthy stuff.
Now, the Food and Drug Administration wants a few more facts on the table.
Last week it announced new rules to require restaurants to back up any nutrition claims on menus.
"Low-fat," you say?
Give me the numbers.
Cite chapter and verse.
Reading menus could soon get pretty strenuous.
Wouldn't it be easier to go for that jog?
COMPANIES Heir a Bit Less Apparent Robert M. Haft had big plans for running the Dart Group -- to "let people make mistakes," to double earnings in four years.
But he may have rolled up his sleeves a bit too soon -- and it could be a costly mistake.
After all, his 72-year-old father, Herbert H. Haft, is still chairman of Dart, and from all appearances did not take kindly to his 40-year-old heir apparent's bold words.
It didn't help his mood to read in April that his son, who had built Crown Books into a power, had been "de facto chief executive" for two years.
Last week the elder Mr.
Haft moved to remove his son from the board -- and with 57 percent of the voting stock, he's likely to get his way.
Opening Up Cable TV It's easy to say that any upstart can get into cable television -- that true competition exists.
But if the little guys can't get HBO, say, or 24-hour sports, what chance do they have?
Not much.
But last week, in a big step toward more competition -- and, very likely, lower prices -- seven top cable companies settled a long antitrust investigation, agreeing to loosen the reins on popular programming.
True, recent legislation mandates much of this, but the pact appears to go further in requiring companies to license channels to rivals that transmit by satellite, microwave or, eventually, phone lines.
So the cable future is heading for your living room, and you may even save a few pennies when it gets there.
Rethinking an S.&amp; L. Deal As the Government rushed to unload insolvent savings and loans, it made some pretty strange deals.
Try this one: In 1988, regulators promised nearly $2 billion in subsidies to James M. Fail to create Bluebonnet Savings from 15 Texas S.&amp; L.'s.
You'd think Mr.
Fail was a solid citizen, and was investing sizable sums of his own.
Not quite.
He'd been indicted for fraud and was barred from doing business in Alabama.
And what came out of his pocket?
A cool $1,000, with the rest borrowed.
Bluebonnet, and Mr.
Fail, are thriving.
The Government, after five years, suddenly came to and said, "Wait a minute!" Last week, regulators sued Mr.
Fail for fraud, saying he had been less than candid about his past.
Lean Profits at Apple Computer Apple Computer is selling a lot more personal computers, but investors are enjoying it a lot less.
Apple said on Wednesday that its earnings would fall, and its shares plunged 10 percent -- ending the week at $43.75, off fully 25 percent since May 20.
The problem, oddly, is that Apple did just what it set out to do: grab more of the PC market.
With sales up 35 percent lately, it has joined I.B.M. at the top of the heap.
But everything conspired to slice away at profits: rivals cut prices, forcing a price war, and as low-end machines became more powerful, more people bought these less-profitable models.
And as computers go from being miracle machines to just another familiar commodity, buyers learn how to avoid paying a penny more than they have to.
Investing in the Printed Word The New York Times Company agreed last week to buy The Boston Globe, New England's largest newspaper, for $1.1 billion.
Both saw clear benefits in the deal: The Globe, owned by two family trusts, avoids any chance of a messy takeover battle when those trusts expire in 1996, while the Times Company extends its reach in the populous corridor from Maine to Washington.
Times stock lost $2.50 on Friday, to $24.375, the day after the announcement.
Affiliated Publications, The Globe's owner, gained 37.5 cents, to $13.625.
INTERNATIONAL France Gives In on Farm Cuts Leading nations have tried for years to find a consensus on world trade, but snags persist.
Here's a big one: The United States says that by subsidizing farmers, Europe holds an unfair edge in the market for oilseed products, but France has resisted cutting output.
It is no small matter, because oilseeds, used for vegetable oils and animal feed, are a huge business.
But last week, possibly feeling world pressure, France dropped its opposition.
Now France will have its hands full calming the irate, and highly vocal, farm lobby.
Club Med Goes to China This just about settles it.
China is joining the 20th century, with all its pains, all its well-scripted pleasures.
Club Med is coming to China.
A year-round resort, complete with golf course and casino, will be built on the island of Hainan.
Club Med clearly could not ignore the Asian appetite for vacations.
In addition to Chinese visitors, it expects many from Japan, Taiwan and Korea.
Japanese, in fact, now make up 6.2 percent of its customers.
No Aristide, No Oil In more poetic times, a face could launch a thousand ships.
These days, it's oil that makes things happen -- or at least that's what the United Nations is betting.
Last week the Security Council decided that since all else had failed, it would play a powerful economic card to pressure Haiti to restore the Rev.
Jean-Bertrand Aristide to power -- it planned to impose a worldwide ban on oil exports to Haiti.
The United States has had an oil embargo for over a year, but diplomats have said that only a global ban could get the attention of Haiti's military rulers.


What Do Clothes Mean To an Artist Anyway?
"FALL FROM FASHION" at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield is not about fashion, at least not in the haute couture or Seventh Avenue sense of the term.
It is rather a comment on clothing and its significance, as perceived by artists.
The show, which was organized by the museum's director, Barry A. Rosenberg, comes with a glossy catalogue.
Unfortunately, too many of its pages are virtually empty and, as if to compensate, the layout is dreadfully tricky.
What is more, the silver cover aims to be provocative by featuring a photograph of a bearded, ponytailed young man in a dowdy dress, along with the question "Are Today's Artists Hung Up on Clothing?"

POSTINGS: Browsers Welcome; House-Hunting, Via Video
It's a bit like an upscale Co-ops 'R' Us.

Angels, lots of angels, with gold wings, lyres and trumpets, hanging from strings, heralding from on high the delights of "full park views," "terrace in bloom," "charming CPW pre-war." The Crooning Game
SOMETHING on the plate is moving.
There among the crisp greens, the handsome radishes and carrots and the proud trio of freshly fried samosas, served among the careful opulence of this fine midtown Indian restaurant, is a little black speck, no bigger than the head of a pin, and Chris Isaak doesn't like it.
No sir, he doesn't like it one bit.
The pompadoured, button-nosed, 36-year-old singer focuses his sharp blue eyes on the offending speck.
He leans in closer, then he turns his gaze upon the waiter, who has just deposited the plate and now stands expectantly at the table.
"Hey!" Mr. Isaak says. "This little guy's still alive."
