Forgotten History: Furgol Won Here
He is Baltusrol's forgotten man.
While the last two Opens here have been celebrated as the site of victories by Jack Nicklaus, unsung Ed Furgol's victory in the Baltusrol Open before those is lost in golf's foggy mid-1950's.
It came after Ben Hogan's epic victory in 1953 at Oakmont outside Pittsburgh, and before Jack Fleck's Cinderella story at Olympic in San Francisco in 1955.


Japan's Ruling Party Learns to Tremble
The Liberal Democratic Party has governed Japan ever since it was formed in 1955, only temporarily shaken by the scandals and fierce rivalries that have periodically brought down governments.
But when Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa lost a no-confidence vote in Parliament Friday night, there was an ominous sense that the future of his once-monolithic party as well as Japan's postwar political order lay in tatters.
Mr.
Miyazawa announced that he would dissolve Parliament and call a snap election after suffering the humiliation, in which 39 members of his own party voted with the opposition.
This time, the stakes in the election will not be which governing party stalwart will succeed Mr.
Miyazawa, but whether opposition parties will join a coalition government with breakaway Liberal Democrats.
Voters are fed up with corruption and want election finance reformed, and a whole new style of government by compromise may have to be invented.

Wall Street; Investors Bring Precious Metals Back in Fashion
INVESTORS are pouring money into precious metals mutual funds and for the short term, at least, the pros seem to think that money is safe.
Gail Dudack, technical analyst at S. G. Warburg &amp; Company, said the surge of interest in precious metals funds itself will help push up prices.
"You're finding a concentration of money going into a small collection of stocks," she explains.
"That will have a bigger-than-life impact."
James Kennedy, portfolio manager of Dreyfus's New Era fund, which invests in inflation hedges such as gold, timber and oil, said he is increasing the gold portion of his portfolio.
Gold makes up about 13 percent of the fund today, up from about seven percent a year ago, he said.
His goal: to have about 20 percent of the portfolio in gold stocks.

As opening arguments began Friday in the trial of three white former officers, many people here wonder whether what happens inside the courtroom will ignite an explosion in the streets.
The trial is expected to last six to eight weeks.

Wallpaper Removal Depends on the Paper
REMOVING wallpaper is always messy, but generally fairly easy.
The methods depend on the type of wallpaper and the wall or ceiling material.
The easiest to remove is so-called strippable paper.
To test removing it, try lifting the corner of a piece with a putty knife.
If the corner comes away easily, peel the paper further by pulling it parallel to the surface, not outward.
If the paper is strippable, entire sheets should be removable by this method.
Underneath may be a layer of backing paper.
That can be left on the wall as a base for new wall covering, but if it comes away in places it has to be removed like ordinary nonstrippable wallpaper.

'Nightline' Wakes Itself Up
It is a little bit more than five hours until air time, and preparations for "Nightline" are running precisely the way Ted Koppel likes them -- just this side of panicked.
Sitting around a long table, Mr.
Koppel and his staff still can't decide on the topic for that night's show.
The executive producer, Tom Bettag, is pushing Waco, which has been the subject of hearings all day on Capitol Hill.
He has lined up three guests in three cities.
Mr.
Koppel is pressing for Bosnia, which has been the focus of tense behind-the-scenes discussions at the White House, but he has secured no guests.
Staff members are dispatched to place calls to Defense Secretary Les Aspin and the United Nations envoy Madeleine Albright.
A talkative general is located, but no camera crew.

Gardeners everywhere usually like to get rid of these invaders as soon as possible.
But they like to do it safely.
In these days of environmental awareness, many gardeners hesitate to use just any spray, but seek the least toxic method.


Lyricist's Household A Blend of Cultures
MARGERY HARNICK was talking about her sea and skyscapes and the exotic handmade paper that textures her paintings.
Nearby, Sheldon Harnick was beaming at his wife's 16 watercolors now hanging in the C.F.M.
Gallery on Greene Street in SoHo, her first extensive collection to be seen in New York City.
Two Long Island exhibitions -- "more abstract and adventurous," Mrs.
Harnick said -- are to open, one on Aug. 7 at the Benton Gallery in Southampton and the other on Aug. 21 at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton.
On a Wednesday afternoon two weeks ago Mr.
Harnick was also edgy.
The next night, "She Loves Me," the 1963 musical, was to open in a new production on Broadway.
Two days later he felt bolstered by the sterling reviews that just might transform from cult to hit status a romantic musical set in a Budapest parfumerie in 1934.
Not that the lyricist of "Fiorello," which had opened four years earlier, and "Fiddler on the Roof," one year later, needs bolstering, but after 30 years it is nice to know that a favorite show's time has come.
Benefit Performance Saturday
Mrs.
Harnick, an artist in ascent, and Mr.
Harnick, who divide their time between an apartment on Central Park West and a house in East Hampton, will appear in "A Broadway Medley -- Hampton Style," one of 16 events next weekend on the South Fork to benefit Guild Hall in East Hampton.
In their hourlong performance at the house of Lillian Braude in East Hampton, the couple will include two selections from "She Loves Me" and two outtakes from "Fiddler on the Roof," "Dear Sweet Sewing Machine" and "The Butcher's Song." Their act is an outgrowth of a joint appearance at Rainbow and Stars in Manhattan several years ago.
"That was a nice detour," Mr.
Harnick recalled.
"But Margery needed to get back to art, and I wanted to go on writing."
Mr.
Harnick's numerous works in progress include a 45-minute cantata, a full-scale version of "Cyrano" and a musical fantasy adapted from a Russian play.
"Sheldon's a good director," Mrs.
Harnick said.
"He knows the essentials he wants from the act."  Former Broadway Performer
Once a Broadway performer under the name of Margery Gray, she worked in two of Mr.
Harnick's shows with scores by Jerry Bock, "Tenderloin" and "Fiorello." "But we weren't going out together then," she said.
"We were married after 'Fiddler.' "
And then Ms.
Gray appeared in, among others, "Tovarich," as the ingenue in the musical starring Vivien Leigh; "Drat, the Cat," as standby for Leslie Ann Warren, and opposite Hal Linden in a revival of "Anything Goes," but no longer in Mr.
Harnick's shows.
"Casts can be sensitive," she said, "and we didn't want it to seem like nepotism. So we kept our work apart."
After their marriage -- her second and his third -- Mr.
Harnick said: "I respected Margery too much to say, 'I hope you give this up.' But I was delighted when she decided she wanted to be home, not rehearsing, or on the road."
They have a son, Matthew, a marine biologist in his 20's who lives in the Hamptons, and a daughter, Beth, from Mrs.
Harnick's previous marriage.
She is a songwriter in her 30's and lives in Los Angeles.
As a wife and mother who sometimes performed on commercials and voice-overs, Mrs.
Harnick tried photography.
Mary Rodgers and Tom Paxton, two neighbors in the Hamptons, bought her work, "but that wasn't hands-on enough," she said.
Awaiting the "You're On" Call
"I grew up with a respect for art, and it was something to do in the dressing room while I was waiting to go on stage," Mrs.
Harnick recalled.
"My mother, Mildred Gray, was a fashion designer. She painted, and she's still at it at 88. While other kids had coloring books, she gave us drawing pads and unchewed pencils."
Musing on her creative beginnings, Mrs. Harnick said:
"All those years dancing in front of multimirrors in a rehearsal hall I was fascinated with the reflections' going out into space, the color play between light and people. I didn't realize that would grow into an obsession, and after I had done a piece of art, what an incredible revelation that I composed it, I lit it, I choreographed it. I did it all myself.
"My work is about nature -- wind, sunsets, things floating in water. People see different things in them, whatever they want it to be, but I know where I'm going before I put it together. It's as if the paper, paper so thin it's translucent when the light comes in, were the paint."
Mrs.
Harnick uses paper made of papyrus, carrots, Japanese rice, eggplant from South America and bark from trees in California.
"Beth sends those," she said.
On the harmony between greasepaint and watercolors in their lives, Mrs. Harnick said:
"We have a station wagon to constantly schlep canvases from New York to East Hampton. I have my own identity, and we do a lot of benefits. We get to rehearse together and laugh. It's the best of both worlds."

New &amp; Noteworthy
BECOMING A MAN: Half a Life Story By Paul Monette.
HarperSanFrancisco, $12.
Winner of the 1992 National Book Award for nonfiction, this autobiography chronicles Paul Monette's struggle to accept his homosexuality after years spent hiding it.
"His fine memoir is affirmative and ultimately celebratory," Wendy Martin said here last year.
A GOOD SCENT FROM A STRANGE MOUNTAIN By Robert Olen Butler.
Penguin, $10.
Robert Olen Butler was an Army linguist in Vietnam and his experience infuses his first collection of short fiction, which won the 1993 Pulitzer Prize.
All 15 stories are told from the point of view of a Vietnamese emigrant to the American Gulf Coast, where his or her sense of loss is less a result of the war than of cultural displacement.
Last year our reviewer, George Packer, praised the stories' originality, calling them "the work of a writer who is intoxicated by Vietnam and the Vietnamese, who loves what has alienated so many other Americans."


Woman in the News; Immigration Expert Who Takes Broad Approach -- Doris Marie Meissner


SAINT HILLARY
Hillary Rodham Clinton has what the Bush Administration was sorely lacking and could grasp only vaguely as "the vision thing" ("Saint Hillary," by Michael Kelly, May 23).

EUGENIA LEE HANCOCK New York, N.Y.


Sprays That Slay Plant Pests, Safely
THE nibblers and chewers are about, those pesky insects that make nasty holes and cause yellow spots in plant leaves.
Gardeners everywhere usually like to get rid of these invaders as soon as possible.
But they like to do it safely.
In these days of environmental awareness, many gardeners hesitate to use just any spray, but seek the least toxic method.


For Many Fathers, Roles Are Shifting
Today, for Father's Day, Johari Abdul-Malik Seale plans to pick up bagels for his wife, Mary, and their two children on his way home to Northwest Washington from his all-night job at Washington Hospital Center.
As he does every morning, he will do a load of laundry.
He and his wife will go running, taking turns pushing one child in their single jogging stroller and carrying the other in a backpack.
Later, they will have cake and ice cream.
Then he will end the day reading to his son and rocking his daughter in a cradle.
Mr.
Seale, a Howard University geneticist, prides himself on his involvement at home.
He even leads a fathers' discussion group at a community center every two weeks.
But trying to become an equal partner with his wife, sharing not just chores but decision-making, has not always been easy.


Playoffs to Decide Who Represents U.S.
SIX days of play beginning on Wednesday in Memphis will determine four teams to represent the United States in the 1993 World Team Championships at Santiago, Chile, in September.
When they get there, all four teams will be among favorites to win world titles.
In the open series, one team may be slightly weaker than it had hoped to be.
Cliff Russell, Sam Lev, Larry Cohen, David Berkowitz, Marty Bergen and Bjorn Fallenius qualified for these playoffs by winning the 1991 Reisinger Teams.
Fallenius had to withdraw because he represents Sweden internationally, and his partner, Bergen, wished to withdraw also.
The team would have added Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, one of the world's best pairs, but the American Contract Bridge League did not allow Bergen to withdraw and he will play an improvised partnership with Rodwell.


As Hispanic Presence Grows, So Does Black Anger
When Cuban refugees began arriving here 30 years ago, Ruth Page was working as a seamstress in a tailoring and cleaning shop, and she says she had no strong feelings one way or another about the Spanish-speaking people.
But when she lost her job to a Cuban, her attitude changed.
Now Mrs.
Page remains resentful,and worried about the still-growing Hispanic presence in Miami.
So when the Dade County Commission met last month to consider abandoning a requirement that all county business be conducted in English, she was one of several black Miami residents who attended the meeting to speak out.

He's a One-Man Team
When JEROME (J.J.) ALEXANDER moved from the Bronx to the tiny Adirondack community of Westport, N.Y., his new high school didn't have a track team.
So he gave them one.
"I wanted to run, I set my mind on it," said Alexander, 17, was born in Trinidad and Tobago, moved to the United States at 3 and grew up in the Bronx, surrounded by drugs and violence.
Summers at a camp in the area helped Alexander fall in love with Wesport and he arranged to spend the school year there with friends.
A sprinter at DeWitt Clinton, he wanted to run for his small school (20 students in his junior class) and received permission to do so as a one-man team.
He competed at dual meets in the 400 meters and triple jump.
"I have no teammates to warm up with," he told The Plattsburgh Press-Republican.
"It's hard, but I've gotten used to it." (AP)

Albert A. Chambers, 86, Bishop Who Fought Women in Priesthood
Albert A. Chambers, a retired bishop who rebelled against the decision of the Episcopal authorities to ordain female priests in the 1970's, died Friday at a hospital in Sun City Center, Fla., where he lived.
He was 86.

JUNE 13-19: Medical Research; New Method for Lessening The Effects of Diabetes
For decades, researchers have argued a key question: Are diabetic complications like eye and kidney damage primarily caused by the presence of high blood sugar or another aspect of the disease?
To find out, researchers divided 1,441 diabetics into two groups.
One received conventional treatment consisting of one or two insulin shots a day, which allowed their blood sugar levels to vary widely.
The others monitored their blood up to seven times and day and gave themselves three to five insulin shots, keeping their blood sugar levels close to normal.


Nantz Decides to Stay With CBS
JIM NANTZ, whose contract with CBS expires at the end of June, has decided to remain with the network rather than move to ABC, a spokeswoman for CBS confirmed yesterday.
ABC had sought to lure Nantz with the promise he would return to calling college football.
He is expected to take over CBS's golf hosting duties when PAT SUMMERALL retires and will continue as the lead announcer for men's college basketball.
Terms of the deal were not announced, and Nantz was unavailable for comment.
"We're happy to have him stay," said SUSAN KERR, the CBS spokesman.


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia; Market Slow, Towers Close
FACING downtown office vacancy rates nearing 20 percent and rents in Class A space close to those being charged in older buildings, some landlords are choosing to close office towers to wait for better days.
At least three have been emptied in recent months and others have been dark for some time.
The 17-story, 258,000-square-foot Avenue of the Arts Building, at Broad and Chestnut Streets, is the largest property emptied.
Shortly before its owner, Meritor/PSFS, was seized by Federal regulators last December, tenants were told the building would be shuttered by March.
The bank had a branch in the building.


Olympus Plan Likely To Raise Taxes
Supporters of the Olympus-Parr Development project are making the impossible assertion that Huntington taxpayers will receive a decrease in their taxes as a result of the project.
Even County Executive Robert J. Gaffney, on a recent radio broadcast made this very claim.
Nothing could be further from the truth.
The public-relations team lobbying to sell the project claims that some amount of payment in lieu of taxes would be paid on the 53.7 acres of state land on which the multimillion-dollar corporate headquarters would be built.
But first the public should know that Olympus and Parr Development may not be paying anything.
The State Urban Development Corporation, after repeated requests under the Freedom of Information Act and a court order, which is being appealed, still won't reveal the content of the property leases involved, thereby making it impossible for homeowners to know what taxes or other payments would actually be required by law.
This alone should arouse suspicion as to who will be paying for what when the deal is completed.
Public-relations talk doesn't legally commit Olympus-Parr to anything.

Kiss Of the Lace
The actress Chita Rivera is not the only one caught in a spider's web.
The summer fashion scene appears to be enveloped in a crochet-and-lace cobweb of sleeveless coats, vests, sweaters, pants and skirts.
This diaphanous style signals a very strong feminine and romantic impulse emerging from the cookie-cutter dominance of T-shirts, jeans and Armani suits.
Today's transparent looks have none of the racy, see-through shock that designers showed in their collections.
While crocheted and lace clothes date to the Edwardian era, they are now being mixed with bodysuits, jeans and shorts, giving the concept a fresh vitality.


Chekhov in a Lifelike Setting
BEHOLD an esthetically correct "Cherry Orchard." In the Rushmore mansion at Woodbury in Orange County the audience regards Chekhov's powerless elite through an arched doorway, on a sprawling lawn and in a grand ballroom.
Liubov Ranyevskaya and her entourage sweep through a real library with a sculptured ceiling, brushing right by spectators seated on the aisle.
When the actors are strolling or waltzing on the grass, the audience watches them through open French doors.
Such stageless environmentally authentic productions bear the catch phrase "site specific." This one is site spectacular.
One could do worse than take in Chekhov's last musings upon life and death on a summer night, on a real country estate, on 10 torchlighted acres, surrounded by some 500 more.
Even when it is less than picture perfect, "The Cherry Orchard," in the second season of the Rushmore Festival of the Arts has three things going for it: location, location, location.


Commercial Property: Looking for the Right Space; Why Mastercard Stayed in Manhattan
AS it turns out, Mastercard International isn't leaving Manhattan after all.
Instead, the fast-growing interbank organization, which has been bursting out of its headquarters space at 888 Seventh Avenue, at 53d Street, will spread out across some 350,000 square feet at 1345 Avenue of the Americas, the old Burlington House at 55th Street.
New York City gets to keep 450 jobs now and a promise of more than double that number before the decade is out.
Mastercard gets as much space as it needs at an excellent price, gets its name on the door of a Class A building in central Manhattan and doesn't have to put any employees through the enervating process of relocating.

TENNIS Navratilova Wins For Martina Navratilova, it was a familiar first step.
First Eastbourne, then Wimbledon.
Seven of Navratilova's nine Wimbledon crowns have followed triumphs on the grass courts at Eastbourne, England.
Yesterday, the top-seeded Navratilova captured a record 11th singles title in this warm-up tournament, defeating Miriam Oremans of the Netherlands, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3.
Oremans, ranked 42d in the world, stunned the American in the first set with a biting serve and competent net play.
The 20-year-old Dutch player, playing in her first final on the women's tour, became rattled in the third set and received a warning for racket abuse after several unforced errors. Leconte, a few weeks shy of his 30th birthday, dominated the match against the 18-year-old Ukranian, who was playing only his second tournament on grass.
Medvedev has climbed to No. 9 in the world after winning two tournaments and reaching the French Open semifinals last month. (AP)

Five hours into the race, the Toyota TS-010 driven by Irvine and Japan's Masanori Sekiya and Toshio Suzuki held about a one-minute lead over the pole-sitting Peugeot 905 of Alliot, fellow Frenchman Jean-Pierre Jabouille and Italian Mauro Baldi.

An Outlet Masquerading as a Gallery
IN Little Italy, Julie Dermansky's storefront gallery provides a refreshing art-world experience.
Ms.
Dermansky, 27, dispenses her own paintings, sculpture, furniture, jewelry, ceramics, collages and art books out of a cluttered shop called J. S. D. Studio, where the floor is thick with paint spatters, an old sign that reads "Segunda Iglesia Pentecostal" still hangs above the door, and prices are as low as $15.
"I opened the store in the spirit of the pop artist Claes Oldenburg, who used to sell his work out of a storefront in the East Village," Ms.
Dermansky said.
"When I moved to New York two and a half years ago, it seemed really difficult to get representation, so I thought, why not open a store?"


Sleeping With the Ghosts of Silver City
ON most evenings the desolate Owyhee mountains in the high sagebrush desert of southwestern Idaho take on a bluish hue as you reach them from the dusty and barren foothills beneath.
I had returned deliberately late in the day to this lonely spot to see the inky blue sky crep over the granite peaks.
And a friend and I planned to spend the night in Silver City, a ghost town over 6,000 feet above sea level that lay 23 miles along a dirt road in the interior of these mountains.
Formerly the jewel of Idaho's mining camps during the gold rush days of the late 1800's, Silver City is a rare example of one that is still intact -- neither gussied up like a theme park after the manner of Deadwood, S.D., or Virginia City, Nev., nor obliterated by modernization.

In This Dream Station Future and Past Collide
Already, it is a landmark: that soaring arch of white steel, rising above granite walls of classical Beaux-Arts grandeur.
Depicted in architect's renderings with sunlight streaming through its sparkling glass skin, the arch brings out the primal emotions aroused by the sight of a rainbow after a storm.
It may be years before this vision materializes.
The $315 million needed to build it is not yet in hand.
But Amtrak's proposal to resurrect Pennsylvania Station from a pit beneath Madison Square Garden and enshrine it within the landmark general post office building across the street has aroused more anticipation than any civic project in years.
No wonder, for this project pushes some of the hottest buttons in architecture and urbanism today.
Public space.
Infrastructure.
Mass transit.
Regional planning.
But the hottest button of all is one that touches off a painful memory: the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station station 30 years ago.
The razing of this station, McKim, Mead &amp; White's 1910 masterpiece of Beaux-Arts design, was one of the greatest traumas New York City ever suffered.
Public reaction was profound, and in some ways beneficial.
Historical preservation was transformed from a genteel pastime to a nationwide movement with political clout.
Architects began to admit that the Modern movement was turning out to be less than a boon for cities.
Above all, New Yorkers began to assert a proprietary interest in the city as their collective cultural heritage.


Who Knows Best?
To the Editor:
I agree with Lawrence O'Toole that putting valuable musical properties to "good, tasteful and interesting" use is a highly subjective task.
But I ask him who is best to make that determination: the director who put Nellie Forbush in a straitjacket, as Mr.
O'Toole reports, or William and James Hammerstein, who observed their father as he created the shows, heard his reactions to numerous performances good and bad, and in the 33 years since his death staged and supervised dozens of productions of these shows?

Lobbyist at Work


At Work; Financing Strategies for Child Care
ALL appearances in Washington to the contrary, an illegal, Social Security-free nanny at home is not the typical child-care arrangement in the United States.
Nearly half of all preschool children with a working mother are in daycare centers or family day care and several million more would be if the slots were available.
The Urban Institute estimates the shortfall at some six million places, caused by lack of capital, low wages that limit the pool of workers and the need to keep the cost to parents at an affordable level.
Child-care experts say the traditional places to turn for help, state and local government, are themselves desperately in need, drained by burdens transferred to them during the Reagan-Bush years.
So, advocates for children are beginning to turn to the private sector.
Policy groups, led by the Center for Policy Alternatives, a Washington research organization, have recently been talking about an innovative financing strategy that uses the Community Reinvestment Act of 1977 to encourage partnerships between banks and child-care providers.
In the best tradition of enlightened self-interest, the tactic could work to the benefit of both.


Perspectives: 40 Wall Street; Asian Buyer Accepts a Leasing Challenge
"THEY wanted a signature building, but anything over $100 million they wouldn't touch," said Edmund Yu, who acted as consultant last year to Hong Kong businessmen seeking a major real-estate investment in New York City.
The search led downtown.
And last month Kinson Properties closed on the purchase of the long-term leasehold to the distinguished if tattered 1.1-million-square-foot skyscraper at 40 Wall Street.
Within weeks, after major new capital investment, the 66-story building is expected to be back on the leasing market.
It is 80 percent vacant.

For the Protection Of Village Residents
It would be inefficient to operate a hospital with a staff composed only of doctors.
This is why there are nurses, practical nurses, nurses' aides and orderlies to meet the varying needs of the patients.
Law enforcement is similar.
It is inefficient to have only police academy graduates -- police officers -- meet the various needs for the security and safety of the residents of different communities.
This is why there are peace officers, code-enforcement officers and security guards to provide the various degrees of protection needed.

Nabisco Stock: A Tough Sell for Morgan Stanley
One nice thing about being a Wall Street underwriter is that mostly you get to sell what investors are dying to have.
These days, that is a category that includes junk bonds and real estate investment trusts.
At its best, the job of the lead underwriter is to decide which eager buyers will be allowed to hand over their money.
But sometimes underwriters must sell what buyers don't covet.
That is when they earn their living, as Morgan Stanley is doing now in trying to sell the new food stock that RJR Nabisco announced in March.
The offering is due late this week.


'Hopefully' Springs Eternal
While the cat is away, let's play with a heretical notion.
Let's engage in a spirited defense of the word hopefully.
You know -- the bad hopefully.
The one without a verb to modify, or even an adjective to modify; the one floating, odd and defiant, at the beginning or the end of a sentence; the one you stop yourself from saying, train yourself never even to think -- that hopefully.
I never touch the stuff, myself, and never will.
I don't have the stomach for it.
My lips draw back from it in horror.
The resulting opprobrium is too great.
I am a novelist, not a revolutionary.
Having made that clear, I would like to say that I am also wrong.

CRIME
What's an Elizabeth George novel without the usual grotesque characters, twisted psyches and monstrous perversities?
A better book, that's what.
The author maintains her florid style, but by toning down the Grand Guignol claptrap that made such an unholy racket in her earlier novels, she finds a stronger voice in MISSING JOSEPH (Bantam, $21.95) to tell the mournful story of a village priest who comes to no good trying to reform his unruly flock.
When the gentle Anglican vicar of Winslough dies from eating hemlock root in a meal prepared by a woman who knows her herbs, the gossips have a field day spreading nasty rumors of murder throughout the country parish.
The herbalist grows sullen and secretive; the unstable constable who is her lover gets mean and ugly; the woman's 13-year-old daughter acts out sexually; and the local witches fire up their caldrons.
By the time the series detectives descend from London on the bleak wintery fields of Lancashire, the scene is well and truly set for a juicy mystery based on the provocative theme of parental love and protectiveness -- and their dangerous outer limits.

Airlines Try Selling the Sizzle, Not the Seat
ALL too often, travelers planning a flight are confronted with choices that leave them feeling as if they are taking a multiple-choice exam with no right answers.
For them, the news is not promising: more choices are coming, but lower prices are not likely to be among them.
The reason is that airlines are scrambling for unique features, many of them made possible by new technology, to draw passengers away from competitors' ticket counters.
The goal is to distract passengers from what is often their top priority when flying, a cheap ticket.
And, adding more irony to the upside-down world of airline economics, such marketing tactics often add to the cost of flying.


Bumped Traveler May Sue
The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in San Francisco, ruled earlier this month that airline passengers can sue for compensatory, but not punitive, damages if they are bumped from flights for which they have a confirmed reservation.
In doing so, it rejected arguments that the Airline Deregulation Act of 1978 barred any claim against carriers under state law.
The decision is applicable in California, Idaho, Montana, Oregon and Washington.
But because the court disallowed the claim for punitive damages, airline officials and consumer advocates do not expect any change in advance booking procedures, nor do they expect a rash of lawsuits.

Hot Hotels
WHAT puts the hot in a hot hotel?
What is it about the Royalton in Manhattan, to take one established example of the genre, that has made it the sexiest place to stay?
Is it Philippe Starck's luxuriously outre big round bathtubs and sleek slate fireplaces?
Or is it just that Ian Schrager, the hotel's owner, is something of a celebrity himself?
Yes, and yes again.
There's a peculiar alchemy between location, design and personality that creates a High Desirability Quotient.
This month there are two new entries in the field: the $360 million Four Seasons in Manhattan and the somewhat more modestly produced Bridgehampton Motel on Long Island.

Stirrings of Self-Restraint on Campaign Spending
CAN Congress reform the way it gets elected?
Can it reduce the influence of special interest money and make it easier for challengers to take on incumbents?
Or are the incentives to do so too feeble to overcome the obvious advantage of the current system?
For each incumbent, the way things now work seems to have produced the proper result: a certificate of election.
And even if change starts appealing to lawmakers, it will be hard for them to make their way through the forest of interparty and House-Senate conflicts.


Fresh Air Hosts Nurtured A Lasting Relationship
Diana C. Vila's childhood was full of adult responsibilities.

But Ms.
Vila could escape.
She could close her eyes and dream about "a pretty white home with the big green lawn where there weren't any problems." It was the home in Pennsylvania Dutch country that she visited every summer through the Fresh Air Fund.


U.S. Steps Up Prosecution Of Sea-Dumping
For years, environmental groups and governments have been complaining about debris dumped from cruise ships that washes up on shores from the Caribbean to Alaska.
Now something is being done about the problem.
In April, Princess Cruise Lines pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Miami to discarding plastic garbage bags off the Florida Keys and paid a record fine of $500,000.
A vigilant passenger with a video camera had recorded the incident.
Officials said the case marked the first successful prosecution of a cruise ship line in a United States court for violations in American waters of international agreements on marine pollution.
Three other cases are being pursued in two Florida jurisdictions, thanks to a 1992 decision by the Coast Guard to stop relying on countries where cruise vessels are registered to carry out such prosecutions.

Conversations/Rita Dove; A Poet's Topics: Jet Lag, Laundry And Making Her Art Commonplace
IT wasn't what she was supposed to do, this poetry business.
As far as her parents knew, Rita Dove was at Miami University studying to be a lawyer.
Back in Akron for Thanksgiving, the young woman sat down with her father, a chemist at Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, and told him she intended to be a poet.
"My father swallowed once and said, 'Well, I've never understood poetry, so don't be upset if I don't read it,' " recalled the country's new poet laureate, her soft voice untouched by regret or resentment.
"That was okay." Although he seemed to feel she was moving to some inaccessible island of the mind, at least she welcomed the honesty.

Profile/Jan Davidson; Is It Learning or Fun? It's Both, She Insists
In 1978, Jan Davidson invested $3,000 in an Apple II for her after-school tutoring business, but she soon found there was no software that met her students' needs.
So she designed a simple program to teach speed reading, had a friend write the computer code and quite unknowingly planted the seeds for what has become one of the three top producers of educational software.
Today Mrs.
Davidson is president of Davidson &amp; Associates, a $40 million company based in this Los Angeles suburb.
Davidson's Math Blaster, an arcade-style game that lets children shoot space aliens out of the sky by solving equations, has sold over 1 million copies, earning it a place in the educational software hit parade along with Broderbund Software's Carmen Sandiego and the Learning Company's Reader Rabbit.

Woodcuts in the Japanese Style; Photos of Japan
OF the two current exhibitions bearing witness to the opening up of Japan in the 19th century, one is at the MacCulloch Hall Historical Museum in Morristown, the other at Rutgers Zimmerli Museum in New Brunswick.
The main gallery at MacCulloch Hall has been born again -- with walls painted a color that lies somewhere between lime and apple green.
Even so, the display of woodcuts by Arthur Wesley Dow (1857-1922) more than holds its own -- as well it might, for Dow was a man intoxicated by color and well before the advent of Orphism and its American counterpart, Synchromism.
One reason the artist's work has not attracted comparable attention from historians may be that, drawing inspiration from Japanese prints, he expressed his chromatic ideas in landscape, rather than in abstractions.
And though he took a "holistic" view that encompassed the decorative arts, he was primarily a printmaker.
Yet as a teacher and writer he exerted considerable influence -- Georgia O'Keeffe, Max Weber and Alvin Langdon Coburn were among his students -- and did much to further the American branch of the Arts and Crafts Movement.


Move to Curb Incentives To Businesses
Concerned that some cities and counties in New York have gone too far in their efforts to attract new jobs and to keep companies that are being wooed by other states, the State Legislature is seriously considering measures that would curtail some of the incentives that could be offered.
The proposals are intended to increase accountability and to limit some of the incentives, like sales-tax waivers, that local industrial development agencies have offered to companies, usually to keep them from leaving town.
While such incentives have been used liberally by New York City to keep companies like Prudential Securities and the Morgan Stanley Group from moving to New Jersey or elsewhere, the legislators say their bills are aimed at abuses that have been reported around the state.

Surge in Free Lunches At Schools a Sign of Tough Times
IN what state and local education officials say is a good measure of a bad economy, the number of children receiving free lunches at schools on Long Island is rising.
Even so, the officials said, many children who qualify for the lunches do not receive them because their parents are afraid or embarrassed to apply.
As more family incomes begin to feel the effects of long-term unemployment, the surge of applications for free or reduced-price lunches, which began to hit districts last year, has continued in the school year that ends this month.
According to the State Education Department, the number of specially priced lunches served on the Island has also grown again.  21% Increase in Two Years
Of the nearly 14 million lunches served in Long Island schools through February of this school year, 34 percent were free or reduced in price, up from 32 percent last year and 28 percent in the 1990-91 school year.
That is, proportionally, a 21 percent increase over the two years.

Correction
An article last Sunday about New York City hotels referred incorrectly to the Latham Hotel.
The building's northern half remains a conventional hotel, the Latham, at 4 East 28th Street; the southern half now operates as a youth hostel and budget hotel, the Gershwin, at 7 East 27th Street.


2 Houses From Hartford's Greener Era
THE corner of Sisson and Farmington Avenues in Hartford has become frumpy over the last century.
Elm-shaded mansions have given way to a submarine-sandwich franchise, a drugstore and monolithic apartment buildings, candy wrappers whirl across the street in the hot summer wind and even pigeons hurry by.
From that vantage point at least, it's hard to believe Mark Twain once called Hartford "a vision of refreshing green." In fact, after his first visit in 1868 to see his publisher, Twain said, "You do not know what beauty is if you have not been here."
He went home to Buffalo, but remained smitten.
Two years later Twain, whose real name was Samuel L. Clemens, decided to transplant himself and his bride to Nook Farm, Hartford's socially progressive settlement of literary figures and philanthropists, which included the author of "Uncle Tom's Cabin," Harriet Beecher Stowe.


Mayors, Meeting in New York, Have Eyes Set on Washington
Five months after a new President took office with a pledge to tackle the problems of the nation's cities, more than 200 mayors gathered in Manhattan yesterday for a meeting dominated by the question: what happened to the early promise of the Clinton Administration?
Many at the 61st convention of the United States Conference of Mayors said that despite Mr.
Clinton's stumbles, they were still optimistic that he would succeed in helping their cities.
But they also said they were disappointed that some of his legislation had foundered -- although they went out of their away to avoid criticizing the President personally.


POSTINGS: Hetrick-Martin; Fewer Sites, More Space
By reducing its quarters from three buildings to one, the Hetrick-Martin Institute in Manhattan is going to be doubling its space.
The 14-year-old institute, which offers education, counseling and support services to lesbian and gay teen-agers, plans to move this fall into 17,000 square feet on the third floor of 10 Astor Place, at Lafayette Street.
As part of the institute, the Harvey Milk School will move to Astor Place from its current home at 401 West Street.
The institute's other programs and offices are operated at 24 Horatio Street and 80 Eighth Avenue.

At AIDS Epicenter, Seeking Swift, Sure Death
Scores of gay men gathered last week in a church meeting room here, at the epicenter of the AIDS epidemic, to learn which drugs to use for suicide, how to avoid a botched attempt and whether to involve their loved ones and doctors.
The unusual how-to seminar was led by Derek Humphry, the founder of the Hemlock Society and the author of a best-selling suicide manual, who said that teaching people to kill themselves was a "sad commentary on our society" but a logical development in a country that largely outlaws doctor-assisted suicide.

Town-House Sales Pick Up as Their Prices Fall Off
LIKE those of much of the New York residential real estate market, the sale prices of one-family town houses in Greenwich Village, the Upper East Side and other prime Manhattan neighborhoods have been, for the most part, falling for the last five years.
The decline, however, has now left prices at what some real estate brokers believe are bargain levels and, according to several recently released reports, has prompted a small resurgence in sales in some parts of the city, particularly on the Upper East Side.


Using Sorrel, A Lemony Accent
ONE year I planted a couple of sorrel seedlings in a corner of my garden.
We had rented the house for the summer and when we returned the following year, I was amazed to see that the entire flower bed had been overrun.
The sorrel had gone to seed and stood two feet high with leaves as big as the pages of a book.
No matter how hard I tried to cut it back, it seemed to grow up again overnight like Jack's beanstalk.
But I love sorrel, and I was delighted to have so much of it.
Sorrel has a sharp, lemony taste that is great with lamb, veal, chicken, fish and eggs.
A few raw leaves are delicious in salads, too (you can add other leaves like nasturtium, basil, lemon balm and young lettuces and dress them with nothing but lemon and olive oil).

In This Dream Station Future and Past Collide
Already, it is a landmark: that soaring arch of white steel, rising above granite walls of classical Beaux-Arts grandeur.
Depicted in architect's renderings with sunlight streaming through its sparkling glass skin, the arch brings out the primal emotions aroused by the sight of a rainbow after a storm.
It may be years before this vision materializes.
The $315 million needed to build it is not yet in hand.
But Amtrak's proposal to resurrect Pennsylvania Station from a pit beneath Madison Square Garden and enshrine it within the landmark general post office building across the street has aroused more anticipation than any civic project in years.
No wonder, for this project pushes some of the hottest buttons in architecture and urbanism today.
Public space.
Infrastructure.
Mass transit.
Regional planning.
But the hottest button of all is one that touches off a painful memory: the destruction of the original Pennsylvania Station station 30 years ago.
The razing of this station, McKim, Mead &amp; White's 1910 masterpiece of Beaux-Arts design, was one of the greatest traumas New York City ever suffered.
Public reaction was profound, and in some ways beneficial.
Historical preservation was transformed from a genteel pastime to a nationwide movement with political clout.
Architects began to admit that the Modern movement was turning out to be less than a boon for cities.
Above all, New Yorkers began to assert a proprietary interest in the city as their collective cultural heritage.


Please Don't Shoot This Player Piano
"Perfection without practice," boasted an advertisement early in the century.
"All the joy without hard work!" said another.
"You need no musical training to play it," proclaimed a third.
So appealing were player pianos that by the 1920's they accounted for more than half the keyboards sold annually in the United States.
Pianists like George Gershwin and Sergei Rachmaninoff recorded piano rolls, paper scrolls intricately perforated so that sensors in the player mechanism could more or less recreate their playing.
Much has changed since then.
Recordings have obviated the need for elaborate pieces of self-playing furniture.
The piano itself has suffered, having lost its prominent place in middle-class domestic life.
It has even acquired an adjective -- acoustic -- to distinguish it from electronic keyboards with no connection to the home and no specified character.

IS HUMANITY SUICIDAL?
Edward O. Wilson argues that we must save other species, not for their own sake, but so "they can be understood and employed in the fullest sense for human benefit" ("Is Humanity Suicidal?" May 30).
What is needed, instead, is to see human beings merely as one part of the whole earth system and probably as that part whose job is to bring about healing, where previously we have caused destruction and degradation.
ELEANOR RAE Ridgefield, Conn.


Shaking It Off
Early last summer, two days after arriving in Belgrade, I was summoned to an interview with Slobodan Milosevic, the Serbian leader I consider a war criminal and a mass murderer.
I was led past a squad of thugs into an ornate chamber and told to wait.
Presently, the stocky English-speaking politician came in smiling.
He extended his hand and I took it.
It is a troubling memory.
Milosevic was not my first despot.
Over the years I had interviewed Idi Amin of Uganda, Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, and the two men who brought Communist rule to Afghanistan, Noor Mohammad Taraki and Hafizullah Amin.
But each of them had maintained autocratic aloofness, showing a contempt for a lowly scribe that I thought was just fine.
I could do my job and they could do theirs.
They never offered their hands.

Boys of Summer Find They're Never Too Old
DIVING to his left, the shortstop, Hank Els, makes a scintillating stop of a hard-hit ground ball.

The play would draw cheers at a game in the major leagues.
On the very next play, the third baseman, Mark Beers, lunges to his left and spears a line drive for another out.
Again, a major-league play.


At the Village Well
To the Editor: I can share some of the feelings about the Welsh language Pamela Petro described in "Gymru and Cymru and All That." I travel often in Wales, and perhaps, someday, I will have the courage to attempt a conversation in Welsh (although courage should not be necessary, since the Welsh are truly kind and helpful).
Potential Welsh learners should know that substantial rewards accrue long before attainment of conversational fluency.
Welsh is so unpredictable that anyone who enjoys languages will become addicted from the first lesson.
As reading facility develops, the learner will enjoy one of Europe's great literatures.
Most poetry is difficult but the sagas are simple, direct, concise and powerful narrative.
"Branwen Ferch Lyr" is a Greek tragedy in prose, 18 pages of elegantly parsimonious narrative (but material for a thousand-page novel) which begin with a pageant of majestic international harmony but soon explode in sadistically murderous violence that pits family against family, stirs up genocidal paranoia, and leaves Branwen to die of grief because "two such marvelous islands" (as Britain and Ireland) have been despoiled on her account.


Airborne Spirits Lose Altitude
WAVE farewell to the three-martini flight.
The days of the airplane as a flying cocktail lounge are pretty much over, as health-conscious passengers and business travelers on tight schedules forgo cocktails and cognacs in favor of a little wine or water.
Overall consumption of alcohol on planes is down, with a decline of about 10 to 15 percent a year for the last several years at most airlines, according to food and beverage managers at major domestic and foreign carriers.
Passengers who do drink spirits tend to drink vodka, but most others are ordering beer or wine or water.


Mount Vernon Gets in Step on Band Day
ON Band Day, a yearly event in June here, this city turned out to celebrate its children.
Thousands gathered along Gramatan Avenue for the event -- a spectacular parade of the marching bands, drill teams and special ensembles of the city's 13 public schools.
Toddlers stared in awe as students from kindergarten through high school marched past, uniformed in glittering colors and showing off skills they had practiced all year.
The drummers were especially exuberant, sending volleys of rhythm into the noonday crowd as sweat from the effort rolled down their cheeks.


Devils Sign Two Young Defensemen
The New Jersey Devils announced Friday the signing of two 19-year-old defensemen, third-round draft choice CALE HULSE and seventh-round selection GEORDIE KINNEAR.
Hulse, a 6-foot-3-inch, 210-pounder played last season for Portland in the Western Hockey League.
He had 10 goals and 26 assists in 72 games and amassed 284 penalty minutes.
Kinnear, 6-1 and 200, played 58 games last season for Peterborough in the Ontario Hockey League, scoring six goals and 22 assists.
He had 161 penalty minutes.

Your Home: The Walk-Through; Inspections That Can Pay Off
IT is customary on the day before a closing for buyers to visit homes they are purchasing one last time to make sure everything is working and it is being left in exactly the condition outlined in the sales contract -- ceiling fixtures, washing machine, dog house, azaleas and all.
Though this particular inspection frequently takes a back seat to other 11th-hour dramas -- documents that must be picked up or final arrangements with the movers -- it should not be lightly dismissed, even if the broker takes it all very casually.


Kamieniecki's Wish Is Nokes's Command
Scott Kamieniecki wanted the ball back for the top of the ninth inning.
He was only a substitute, a call-up starter asked to do the job while Jim Abbott is on the disabled list.
He had never pitched a complete-game victory in the major leagues.
He had not won two games in a row for almost a year.
He wanted the chance.
Yankees Manager Buck Showalter set this as his rule: If the Yankees could get one more run in the bottom of the eighth inning yesterday, if they could increase their lead over the Minnesota Twins to four runs, he would let Kamieniecki go back out for the ninth.


'Backlash' Pops Up As Prop du Jour
Once there was a serious book of feminist reportage.
"Hey, honey," some slick director told the book, "I can make you a star." Something like that must have happened, because suddenly Susan Faludi's best-selling "Backlash: The Undeclared War Against American Women" has become a movie icon.
The 1991 book appears on screen as a conspicuous and jokey prop in two current films and is the subject of a catty reference in a third.
When "Backlash" turns up in the movies, you can hear the Zeitgeist calling.
In "Indecent Proposal," Demi Moore walks into the office of the billionaire businessman played by Robert Redford.
His receptionist shows every sign of being a bimbette -- bleached-blond hair, heavy makeup, lethal fingernails -- except she is reading "Backlash."

Where Chinese Yearn for 'Beautiful' U.S.
As the hogs outside grunted their protests at the drizzle, R. T. Liang sipped cheap tea from one of his set of cracked cups and spoke of the Beautiful Country with a reverence that Americans might find both flattering and unsettling.
"The United States -- what a place!" Mr.
Liang said wistfully, as family members clustered around him in his home, next to a porcelain God of Wealth apparently erected less in gratitude than in hope.
"It's so rich! If there weren't restrictions, everybody would leave here. We would go to look for work in America, Hong Kong or Taiwan. If we could figure out how to get there, we would all go. The villages would become empty."


A 'Taming of the Shrew' That Trusts in Love
IF only as a truce in the ceaseless battle of the sensibilities over what "The Taming of the Shrew" means -- is it a feminist parable? a sexist put-down? -- the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival staging of Shakespeare's provoking comedy is to be embraced with a relieved sigh.
Make love, not war, Dylan Baker's saucy staging seems to be saying, and with that, the weight of decoding Shakespeare with cryptic and coy interpretations is lifted.
Here is a successful production that takes the side of benevolent reconciliation.


Empire Audits Show $51 Million Inflated In '89-90 Loss Data
Internal auditors examining two sets of books kept by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield have found new discrepancies showing that losses on the company's "high-risk" accounts were exaggerated by $51 million in reports filed with New York State regulators in 1989 and 1990.
Last week, the company acknowledged exaggerating its losses by at least $28 million in 1991.
The false reports to the state apparently started about the time Empire, the nation's largest nonprofit health insurer, began an intense lobbying campaign for sweeping changes in state insurance law.
The campaign was based on the premise that Empire was unfairly burdened with high-risk customers.
These were generally the oldest and sickest New Yorkers, whom the for-profit insurers were not required to take, but they also included self-employed people and others who could not get insurance elsewhere.

A Child So Light He Could Fly
There's more than a whiff of menace in MR.
SUMMER'S STORY (Knopf, $17), a seemingly sprightly fable of childhood adventure and discovery by the German novelist Patrick Suskind, whose malevolent first novel, "Perfume," was an international best seller.
Unlike most coming-of-age stories, this one explores not only the mysteries of duty and desire, injustice, aging and death -- but also Galileo's laws of falling bodies.
Set in a pleasant lakeside village "shortly after the war," the tale is narrated by a nameless boy who loves his typically incomprehensible parents, dotes on his elusive sweetheart and despises his hilariously cranky piano teacher.
Gravity (and perhaps gravitas) enters the life of this child "so light I could fly" in the form of the mysterious Mr.
Summer, an eccentric recluse who spends all his time ferociously striding about the countryside, and whose single utterance is an angry "Why can't you just leave me in peace!" Like a force of nature, Mr.
Summer pulls the airy narrator down to earth, providing sobering lessons about childhood foibles and grown-up fears.
And if the translation by John E. Woods occasionally provides a few thuds of its own ("They were only dreams, and like all dreams not really emotionally satisfying"), the accompanying drawings by Jean-Jacques Sempe have the ethereal quality of innocence just on the brink of being lost.

Taking the Measure of Summer Stock
THE defective septic system that caused Gateway's Candlewood Playhouse to shut down in New Fairfield last year has been replaced.
And the Ivoryton Playhouse had a new staircase built in accordance with fire regulations.
While the removal of fire and health code violations are hardly the stuff of inviting theater news, it's the repairs and the numerous renovations, not the repertory, that tell the story of Connecticut's summer stock.
What's left of it.
Ivoryton Playhouse, beginning its 64th season, one ahead of the Westport Country Playhouse, is the winner in the survival game.
But statistics simplify.
They do not reflect changes.


In the Region: Connecticut; State Eases the Plight of Small Landlords
IN the final hours of the last day of the legislative session on June 9, Connecticut lawmakers made life marginally easier for the state's mom-and-pop landlords.
They passed a bill that permits direct payment of rent by city welfare agencies to the landlord after one month of nonpayment by the tenant.
But measures that would speed the eviction process, and let towns require rent to be paid into the local housing court until the landlord gets a certificate of occupancy, did not reach the floor.
Currently, tenants may stop paying rent when no such certificate exists.

In the Cause of New War Memorials
THREE new commemorative coins honoring Americans who served in World War II will be issued by the United States Mint beginning July 9.
The coins come in denominations of $5, $1 and a half-dollar.
The profits will be used to create a memorial in Washington to all those who served in the war and to help pay for a United States D-Day and Battle of Normandy Memorial in Normandy, France.
The Mint is authorized to issue 300,000 $5 coins, a million $1 coins and two million half-dollar coins.


Shrimpers Voice Fear On Growth of Factory
Out on San Antonio Bay, as a hazy Texas sun arches overhead, shrimp trawlers with names like the Lady Harvester and the Gulf Tide drag their nets placidly back and forth before puttering back to the fish markets here for a decades-old ritual of local commerce.
Tens of thousands of bay shrimp pass along conveyor belts, then are cleaned, weighed, packed in ice and bartered over. (Current price, 65 cents or so a pound.)
But the languorous pace in the fishing villages along this stretch of the Gulf of Mexico belies a profound anger among those whose livelihood has long been tied to the seafood-rich bays and estuaries of the Texas coast.

A Long Shot for Casinos: Sports Betting on Ballot
In a campaign akin to a political race, the Casino Association of New Jersey is conducting a last-ditch effort to get a sports betting referendum on the ballot in November.
The association, which represents the 12 Atlantic City casinos, is in the final week of a two-week, $500,000 campaign that has included newspaper, television and radio advertisements, mailings to state legislators and the recruitment of gamblers off gaming floors.


Confessions of a Rider On Metro-North   I laughed when I read Kate Stone Lombardi's article "A Who's Who of the Commute" (May 30) describing the four types of Metro-North commuters.   I was definitely a "worker" type. For three years, while I commuted from my home in Westchester to law school in Manhattan, "my" seat on the train was the one nobody wanted -- the windowless corner seat across from the bathroom. Yes, it had dim lighting, cramped leg space and the often unsavory odors emanating from the nearby lavatory. But to a law student it had the perfect combination of privacy and lack of distractions.


Giving the Boot To Soccer Critic
To the Sports Editor:
Even though Richard Sandomir admits a certain "xenophobia," his lack of understanding concerning American soccer fans' appreciation of the game borders on offensive ("Soccer and Television Make a Bad Sports Mix," The Times, June 15).
First of all, "continuous play without commercials" is hardly a "revolutionary . . . big innovation." Soccer fans have been frustrated for decades missing live play during commercials of N.A.S.L. and World Cup matches while scrambling to find the same game on non-English speaking telecasts.
Also by the nature of continuous play, virtually every soccer telecast is guaranteed to be under two hours.


Human Rights: The West Gets Some Tough Questions
IT is tempting to reduce the global human rights debate today to a clash of good guys against bad guys, of Western democracies against Asian dictatorships, of countries defending the principle of universal human rights against third world attempts to water down the concept with economic, cultural and religious arguments.
It is all the more tempting because the attack on traditional "Western" human rights is being led by the likes of China, Syria and Iran, countries not exactly renowned for their love of democracy.
Further, with barely a blush, the Asian bloc seems to have assumed the Soviet bloc's old role of opposing international "meddling" on human rights.

Giving Voice to the Renaissance in Siena. Siena?
Sculptor, painter, architect, engineer, theorist and, in general, "homme extraordinaire," Francesco di Giorgio can lay claim to the dubious honor of being the most undervalued artist of the 15th century.
Sit through a course on the Renaissance and chances are his name will not be mentioned: he was a nova in that constellation of Italian artists that held all Europe in thrall.
The problem is that he was born a Sienese, and as all visitors to that Tuscan city know, Siena and its artists are synonymous with the Middle Ages.
Writing on the occasion of a visit in 1873, Henry James remarked that "other places perhaps may treat you to as drowsy an odor of antiquity, but few exhale it from so large an area."
The means of rectifying this neglect has been provided in the form of a lucidly conceived exhibition, "Francesco di Giorgio and the Sienese Renaissance: 1450-1500," on view here through July 31 in the church of Sant' Agostino.
The exhibition, which includes 120 paintings, sculpture, drawings and manuscript illuminations, is as rich and multifaceted as the personalities it features.
Foremost among these is the great Florentine sculptor Donatello, who spent the years 1457 to '59 in Siena; Francesco's mentor, the sculptor-painter Vecchietta; his associate Nerroccio de' Landi; and the North Italian miniaturists Girolamo da Cremona and Liberale da Verona, who were called upon to illuminate the choirbooks of the cathedral.

Wallpaper Removal Depends on the Paper
REMOVING wallpaper is always messy, but generally fairly easy.
The methods depend on the type of wallpaper and the wall or ceiling material.
The easiest to remove is so-called strippable paper.
To test removing it, try lifting the corner of a piece with a putty knife.
If the corner comes away easily, peel the paper further by pulling it parallel to the surface, not outward.
If the paper is strippable, entire sheets should be removable by this method.
Underneath may be a layer of backing paper.
That can be left on the wall as a base for new wall covering, but if it comes away in places it has to be removed like ordinary nonstrippable wallpaper.

Japan's Crisis: U.S. to Profit?
For the better part of four decades America has held tight to the view that the unshakable dominance of a single, conservative party in Japan is essential to Washington's most critical alliance in the Pacific -- first as a bulwark against Communism, and second as a platform for one of the world's most remarkable economic success stories.
But as the party grew bloated with power, and the endless payoffs and influence-peddling became an international embarrassment for Japan, American officials increasingly found themselves forced to avert their eyes from the system's rotting core.

Older Musicians Playing With Brio

To prove his point, the 87-year-old founder and conductor emeritus of the Eastern Connecticut Symphony, created the National Senior Symphony in 1989 and is now ready to convene its fifth annual assembly in New London.
There's an opening party tonight, but starting first thing tomorrow morning these mostly-retired musicians, ranging from top-notch professionals (the group's concertmaster, Donald Radding, recently stepped down after 43 years as a violinist with the National Symphony) to people 50 and older who simply enjoy playing, will spend four days in orchestral, sectional and chamber rehearsals at the Radisson Hotel.


Israel Seeks to Keep North Korea From Aiding Iran
Although the countries have no diplomatic relations, Israel has quietly had a series of contacts with North Korea, hoping that a lure of economic cooperation may stop the Koreans from providing nuclear technology and a nuclear-capable missile to Iran, officials here say.
The missile, Rodong 1, also known as Scud-D, is still being developed.
But Israeli officials have already expressed great concern because it is believed able to carry nuclear or chemical warheads and because, unlike earlier generations of the Scud, it has a stated range of about 600 miles and would put Israel within striking distance of missile sites in western Iran.


Winning Moves


Regulating Travel Insurers
New York State will regulate travel insurance more strictly starting July 1.
After a review starting in 1991 and a public hearing in January on its handling of insurance against 300 types of "special risks," the state Insurance Department concluded that trip cancellation, accidental death on a trip, lost luggage and similar problems did not constitute a "special risk," as insuring a skydiver did.
So all underwriters of travel insurance packages delivered in New York State must get approval for their rates and forms before selling the policies.
Formerly, most policies were sold under the looser "special risk" provisions without prior approval.
So far, seven companies have submitted policies to the Insurance Department for approval: BCS Insurance Company of Chicago; National Union Fire of the American International Group in New York; TransAmerica of Los Angeles; Mutual of Omaha; Federal Insurance of Chubb of New Jersey; Travelers Insurance in Hartford, and Twin Cities Fire of the Hartford Company.

Oblique Angles Deserve Applause
To the Editor:
No doubt sexiness, along with realism, went out of Hollywood movies in 1934 when the Production Code came in, as Caryn James points out in "Movies Used to Be Really Good by Being Bad"  [ May 30 ] .
But sexiness wasn't always replaced by "coyness and romantic haze," as she seems to think.
The popular arts are often at their most inventive and entertaining when they come up against the stops of the form and the culture and they have to deal obliquely with what can't be shown explicitly.


Railroads Are a Growth Industry, for a Change
IN Washington, the Virginia Railway Express is about to celebrate its first anniversary, carrying commuters from Union Station to Manassas and Fredericksburg.
Amtrak is well on the way to a historic improvement in the tracks from New York to Boston, electrifying those east of New Haven with overhead power lines that will allow faster trips, possibly luring substantial patronage from the air shuttles.
And in Miami, a makeshift commuter line that helped to ease traffic to West Palm Beach during major construction on Interstate 95 is now permanent.
Railroads are trying to make a comeback.
Around the country, air pollution from cars seems to be a nearly intractable problem, and society is concluding that in many places it cannot build enough highways or runways to cure congestion.
The decision to build commuter rail lines, said William E. Loftus, president of the American Short Line Railroad Association, is "a recognition that you can live an hour away from work and still have a pleasant commute."

Don't Let the Pesticide Polluters Fool You; We're All Lab Animals
To the Editor:
Re "Mother Nature's Pesticide Factory" by Michael Fumento (Op-Ed, June 9): Environmentalists are correct in wanting to ban potentially toxic chemicals, and Carol Browner, Environmental Protection Administrator, is equally justified in seeking a revision of the Delaney Clause, though not for the right reasons.
Since 1958 the Delaney Clause has allowed innacurate and misleading data to steer regulation.
Until the flawed methodology behind its guidelines is replaced, humans will continue to be industry's real guinea pigs, irrespective of the chemicals tested.


Using Sorrel, A Lemony Accent
ONE year I planted a couple of sorrel seedlings in a corner of my garden.
We had rented the house for the summer and when we returned the following year, I was amazed to see that the entire flower bed had been overrun.
The sorrel had gone to seed and stood two feet high with leaves as big as the pages of a book.
No matter how hard I tried to cut it back, it seemed to grow up again overnight like Jack's beanstalk.
But I love sorrel, and I was delighted to have so much of it.
Sorrel has a sharp, lemony taste that is great with lamb, veal, chicken, fish and eggs.
A few raw leaves are delicious in salads, too (you can add other leaves like nasturtium, basil, lemon balm and young lettuces and dress them with nothing but lemon and olive oil).

1893 FAIR RECALLED

Flights Of Artistic Fancy
A TWIST of the imagination can transform practical crafts into art forms.
At the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery in Millburn, Marylou Higgins's vessels, candle holders, teapots, necklaces and tables have one thing in common: their surfaces are covered with realistic portraits of imaginary people.
In Fair Lawn, the Kornbluth Gallery's display of garden accessories includes a ceramic wart hog by Hilda Hortens and Elyse Saperstein's grimacing lizard; both are functional planters.
Ms.
Higgins has portrayed literally hundreds of faces and small sculptured figures on her 74 pieces.
Some are drawn with a special pencil on bisque-fired clay, others are painted in soft glaze tones and framed in lustrous borders of gold and silver.


The 'Timeless Genius' Of 'Gilligan's Island'
To the Editor:
Among the litany of pop culture horrors that William Grimes warns are returning to haunt us ("Revival of the Fittest, May 23), the enduring "Gilligan's Island" is described as "little more than a situation and a handful of little-known actors with a laugh track attached." That critique misses the timeless "genius" of that show. Its characters and comedic structure are shamelessly lifted from commedia dell'arte, the proletariat political street farce of the Italian Renaissance.


Mountain, Sea and Story At Clew Bay
"THE most beautiful view I ever saw in the world," wrote William Makepeace Thackeray in 1842 of Clew Bay.
It was his first visit to this beguiling sweep of water speckled with 365 oddly shaped islands amid the bleak mountains and boglands of County Mayo.
The sun was just setting as the carriage bearing the author-to-be of "Barry Lyndon" and "Vanity Fair" rounded Croagh Patrick and rumbled along the coast road on into Westport: "The mountains were tumbled about in a thousand fantastic ways and . . . the bay . . . which sweeps down to the sea, and a hundred islands in it, were dressed up in gold, and purple, and crimson, with the whole cloudy west in a flame. Wonderful, wonderful!"
In the 150 years since Thackeray -- who was usually more prone to satire than hyperbole -- published his sharply observant travel narrative "The Irish Sketchbook," little has changed along the shores of Clew Bay.
A paved road now winds among the villages and resorts along the north-facing coast, spilling out onto the pier at Roonagh Quay, meandering inland through the pub-lined main street of Louisburgh, and skirting the swatch of brilliant white sand against the bay's dark aqua at Old Head Beach.
Just to the east, the mottled green and black slopes of Croagh Patrick loom above the ancient path that in pre-Christian times brought crowds of pilgrims to the mountain's base for a festival honoring the Celtic god Lug, long before St.
Patrick and his followers spread the new faith to the West of Ireland.


The Dinosaur Era, Frozen in Amber
AS thousands of moviegoers in 39 theaters across the state stood on long lines last weekend to see Steven Spielberg's dinosaur epic, "Jurassic Park," researchers from the American Museum of Natural History in New York were unearthing ancient material in New Jersey that, at some point in the distant future, could make the movie's scientific premise a reality.
The film, based on Michael Crichton's best-selling 1990 novel, centers on a theme park built on a remote island off Costa Rica where dinosaurs roam in jungle habitats bound by electrified fences.
The dinosaurs are clones, created from DNA extracted from parasitic insects that had ingested dinosaur blood and then been imbedded in tree resin.
When the resin hardened into amber, the film suggests, the insects -- and the dinosaur blood -- were preserved.


Setting the Pace in the Cafe Competition
CASUAL Italian cafes are more numerous on Long Island than sun-bathers at the beach on a glorious summer day.
Yet, just as every June day is not picture perfect, all pasta-pizza cafes are not alike.
Blue skies are more likely when a cafe is in the hands of experienced restaurateurs.
That is the case at the new Caffe Milano in Woodmere.
It has the same owners as three of the Island's top-rated Italian restaurants, Navona in Great Neck, Stresa in Manhasset and Trattoria Tulipano in Huntington.


Using Sorrel, A Lemony Accent
ONE year I planted a couple of sorrel seedlings in a corner of my garden.
We had rented the house for the summer and when we returned the following year, I was amazed to see that the entire flower bed had been overrun.
The sorrel had gone to seed and stood two feet high with leaves as big as the pages of a book.
No matter how hard I tried to cut it back, it seemed to grow up again overnight like Jack's beanstalk.
But I love sorrel, and I was delighted to have so much of it.
Sorrel has a sharp, lemony taste that is great with lamb, veal, chicken, fish and eggs.
A few raw leaves are delicious in salads, too (you can add other leaves like nasturtium, basil, lemon balm and young lettuces and dress them with nothing but lemon and olive oil).

A Dual View of Debussy
The English pianist Paul Crossley has taken a cleansing look at Debussy's "Preludes," to begin his survey of the composer's complete piano music (Sony Classical SK 52583 and 53111; two CD's).
Also included here are both books of "Images," "Children's Corner," "Estampes" and "La Plus que Lent."
Mr.
Crossley offers considerable pleasure even before he plays a note.
He writes as interestingly about Debussy's music as he plays it.
And when, in his program notes, he wants to put his finger on one of music's most elusive methodologies, he wisely quotes the composer himself.


Mentor to Some, Cult Leader to Others
TO his followers, he is Rama, a gifted teacher and spiritual leader with special powers who offers a path to enlightenment, happiness and career success.
To his detractors, he is everything from a sophisticated con man to a dangerous cult leader.
Controversy has surrounded Dr.
Frederick P. Lenz for the last 15 years as he has moved his base of operations to different cities around the country.
Trina Walker, a former student, said that Dr.
Lenz has more than a hundred students in Westchester County.
He offers lectures at several places, including regular monthly lectures, by invitation only, at the Performing Arts Center at the State University of New York at Purchase.
The group has been renting space at SUNY for three years but is not affiliated with the college.


Mutual Funds; Shut Out? No Reason for Frenzy
MUTUAL fund investors have been frustrated by a rash of fund closings lately: Lindner Dividend, Strong Common Stock, T. Rowe Price Small Cap Value, Monetta and Pennsylvania Mutual have all shut their doors to new investors in recent months.
Some investors have been reacting by rushing to buy before the scheduled closing.
In an extreme case, a Chicago couple drove to St.
Louis to deliver an application for Lindner Dividend on the eve of the deadline.
But is this behavior warranted?


Bill Clinton's Brightening Sky
What a difference a week makes.
Here was an Administration bloodied by self-inflicted wounds and reduced to arguing that it was not incompetent.
And then, surprisingly, came three real achievements on a single day: committee approval in both the Senate and House of President Clinton's national service program, serious progress on campaign finance reform and a big victory in the Senate Finance Committee for the deficit-reduction plan that lies at the heart of Mr.
Clinton's strategy for economic renewal.
The optical lesson is that a modest amount of substantive achievement can overcome a whole lot of stylistic failure.
Only the most churlish opponent could fail to smile upon Mr.
Clinton's overdue good fortune; indeed, one could almost hear a collective sigh of relief not only among the President's friends but also among puzzled citizens who had begun to wonder whether Mr.
Clinton would ever locate the leadership capacities he left lying around the White House a few months ago.


Ease Up!
To the Sports Editor:
During the 40 years I have lived here, and especially when the salaries of star athletes rose to the stratosphere, it seems there has always been at least one athlete on the receiving end of the contumely of the local press corps: Reggie Jackson, Dave Winfield, Darryl Strawberry, and now Bobby Bonilla ("Lost in a City He Calls Home," The Times, April 25).
Strangely enough, they all seem to be black and/or Hispanic.
Once one is driven out of town via trade or whatever, once the atmosphere is so poisoned that life becomes intolerable for the athlete, there is a round of self-congratulation by sports reporters about what a tough town New York is.

Flying to Florida
To the Editor: I am writing to add my voice to the chorus of outraged and disappointed travelers on Skybus.
In February I purchased round-trip tickets (Newark-Fort Lauderdale) for myself and my daughter.
As I informed Skybus, the sole purpose of the trip was a brief visit to my elderly father, who was hospitalized in Florida.
The tickets were for departure on Feb. 5 and return Feb. 6.
We arrived on time and waited in line for almost two hours.
We were then curtly informed that our plane would not depart at 7 P.M., as scheduled, but at 1 A.M. the next day -- meaning that we would arrive in Fort Lauderdale at 5 A.M., the same day we would have to leave.


New Hockey Museum in Toronto
Civic boosters in Toronto like to say it is a world-class city of many dimensions, including sports.
The diverse, modern metropolis on the shore of Lake Ontario boasts of the Blue Jays, who won baseball's World Series last fall and play in a stadium with a retractable dome, quite a tourist attraction in itself.
And there is serious discussion about the National Basketball Association expanding north of the border and putting a team in the city.
Still, Toronto's sports soul belongs to hockey, and it is hockey, particularly Canadian hockey, that is honored in a new museum, the Hockey Hall of Fame, which opened last week.


Landmarking Enters the Jet Age
Mammon and modernism dominated the agenda of the Landmarks Preservation Commission last Tuesday.
It considered giving landmark status to six grand banking rooms in Brooklyn and Manhattan that resemble temples, basilicas and palazzi.
Perhaps more remarkably, it examined the gull-like T.W.A. terminal at Kennedy International Airport, the crystalline former Pepsi-Cola Building on Park Avenue, a glass-fronted town house by Philip Johnson and two interiors at the New School for Social Research: the egg-shaped auditorium and a classroom with murals by Jose Clemente Orozco.


BOMB KILLS SEVEN IN A CAIRO STREET
A nail-packed bomb exploded late Friday in a crowded Cairo street, killing 7 people and wounding 15, in the latest incident in what appears to be a new and deadlier round of urban warfare in Egypt's capital.
The explosion killed and wounded vendors and men sipping tea in a small cafe.
It was the fifth bombing in a public place in the last four months.

AT Norfolk, in the foothills of the Berkshire Mountains, Fred and Mary Ann McGourty have tucked Molly the Witch in a raised flower bed near a Korean Stewartia tree.
As the owners of Hillside Gardens and Nursery, the couple hope that the rare peony will become another hallmark of their perennial paradise.
On six gently sloping acres, impressionistic displays of flowers set against the backdrop of the couple's 18th-century home to provoke the senses as well as the mind.
